         <th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th>
         <td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Vunblist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Vunblist (page does not exist)">Template:Vunblist</a></td>

<p><b>China</b> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a>), officially the <b>People's Republic of China</b>, is a sovereign state located in <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia (page does not exist)">East Asia</a>. It is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" title="List of countries by population">most populous country</a>, with a population of over 1.35&#160;billion. The PRC is a <a href="/wiki/Single-party_state" title="Single-party state">single-party state</a> governed by the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party</a>, with its seat of government in the capital city of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing (page does not exist)">Beijing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Walton2001_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Walton2001-9">[9]</a></sup> It exercises jurisdiction over 22 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a>, five <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a>, four <a href="/w/index.php?title=Direct-controlled_municipalities_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Direct-controlled municipalities of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">direct-controlled municipalities</a> (Beijing, <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>), and two mostly self-governing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Special_Administrative_Region_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">special administrative regions</a> (<a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>). The PRC also claims <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_area_of_the_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free area of the Republic of China (page does not exist)">Taiwan</a> – which is controlled by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of China (page does not exist)">Republic of China</a> (ROC), a separate political entity – as its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">23rd province</a>, a claim which is controversial due to the complex <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan" title="Political status of Taiwan">political status of Taiwan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Covering approximately 9.6&#160;million square kilometers, China is the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_land_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and outlying territories by land area (page does not exist)">second-largest country by land area</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-listofcountriesoftheworld.com_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-listofcountriesoftheworld.com-11">[11]</a></sup> and either the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area" class="mw-redirect">third or fourth-largest by total area</a>, depending on the method of measurement.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> China's landscape is vast and diverse, ranging from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mongolian-Manchurian_grassland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mongolian-Manchurian grassland (page does not exist)">forest steppes</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gobi_Desert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gobi Desert (page does not exist)">Gobi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Desert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Desert (page does not exist)">deserts</a> in the arid north to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subtropical&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subtropical (page does not exist)">subtropical</a> forests in the wetter south. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Himalaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Himalaya (page does not exist)">Himalaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Karakoram" title="Karakoram">Karakoram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pamir_Mountains" title="Pamir Mountains">Pamir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tian_Shan" title="Tian Shan">Tian Shan</a> mountain ranges separate China from South and Central Asia. The <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow Rivers</a>, the third- and sixth-longest in the world, run from the <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Plateau" title="Tibetan Plateau">Tibetan Plateau</a> to the densely populated eastern seaboard. China's coastline along the Pacific Ocean is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> long, and is bounded by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bohai_Sea&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bohai Sea (page does not exist)">Bohai</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_China_Sea" title="South China Sea">South China Seas</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pre-Imperial_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pre-Imperial China (page does not exist)">ancient Chinese civilization</a> – one of the world's earliest – flourished in the fertile basin of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in the <a href="/wiki/North_China_Plain" title="North China Plain">North China Plain</a>. For millennia, China's political system was based on hereditary monarchies, known as <a href="/wiki/Dynasties_in_Chinese_history" title="Dynasties in Chinese history">dynasties</a>, beginning with the semi-mythological <a href="/wiki/Xia_Dynasty" title="Xia Dynasty">Xia</a> of the Yellow River basin (c. 2000 BCE). Since 221 BCE, when the <a href="/wiki/Qin_Dynasty" title="Qin Dynasty">Qin Dynasty</a> first conquered several states to form a Chinese empire, the country has expanded, fractured and been reformed numerous times. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_China_(1912%E2%80%931949)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of China (1912–1949) (page does not exist)">Republic of China</a> (ROC) overthrew the <a href="/wiki/Qing_Dynasty" title="Qing Dynasty">last dynasty</a> in 1911, and ruled the <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">Chinese mainland</a> until 1949. After the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the Communist Party defeated the nationalist <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> in mainland China and established the People's Republic of China in Beijing on 1 October 1949, while the Kuomintang relocated the ROC government to its present capital of <a href="/wiki/Taipei" title="Taipei">Taipei</a>.
</p><p>Since the introduction of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_economic_reform&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese economic reform (page does not exist)">economic reforms in 1978</a>, China has become one of the world's <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by real GDP growth rate (page does not exist)">fastest-growing</a> major economies. As of 2013, it is the world's second-largest economy by both <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">nominal total GDP</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">purchasing power parity (PPP)</a>, and is also the world's largest exporter and importer of goods.<sup id="cite_ref-ChinaBiggestTrader_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaBiggestTrader-12">[12]</a></sup> China is a recognized <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons state</a> and has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_active_troops" title="List of countries by number of active troops" class="mw-redirect">largest standing army</a>, with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by military expenditures (page does not exist)">second-largest defense budget</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ChineseNukes_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChineseNukes-13">[13]</a></sup> The PRC has been a <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> member since 1971, when it replaced the ROC as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council (page does not exist)">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">U.N. Security Council</a>. China is also a member of numerous formal and informal multilateral organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=BRICS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BRICS (page does not exist)">BRICS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BCIM&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BCIM (page does not exist)">BCIM</a> and the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20</a>. China is a regional power within Asia and has been characterized as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potential_superpowers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potential superpowers (page does not exist)">potential superpower</a> by a number of commentators.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Chinese/China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Chinese/China (page does not exist)">Template:Chinese/China</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Contains_Chinese_text&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Contains Chinese text (page does not exist)">Template:Contains Chinese text</a>
The word "China" is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> word <i>Cin</i> (چین), which is from the <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> word <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinas (page does not exist)">Cīna</a></i> (चीन).<sup id="cite_ref-AmHer_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AmHer-16">[16]</a></sup> It is first recorded in 1516 in the journal of the Portuguese explorer <a href="/wiki/Duarte_Barbosa" title="Duarte Barbosa">Duarte Barbosa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> The journal was translated and published in England in 1555.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> The traditional theory, proposed in the 17th century by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martino_Martini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martino Martini (page does not exist)">Martino Martini</a>, is that <i>Cīna</i> is derived from "Qin" (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Linktext&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Linktext (page does not exist)">Template:Linktext</a>), the westernmost of the Chinese kingdoms during the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Dynasty" title="Zhou Dynasty">Zhou Dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Martini_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martini-19">[19]</a></sup> However, the word was used earlier in <a href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> scripture, including the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mah%C4%81bh%C4%81rata&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahābhārata (page does not exist)">Mahābhārata</a></i> (5th century BC) and the <i><a href="/wiki/Manusm%E1%B9%9Bti" title="Manusmṛti">Laws of Manu</a></i> (2nd century BC).<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>The official name of the present country is the People's Republic of China (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a>). The common Chinese names for the country are <i>Zhōngguó</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a>, from <i>zhōng</i>, "central" or "middle", and <i>guó</i>, "state" or "states," and in modern times, "nation") and <i>Zhōnghuá</i> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Zh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Zh (page does not exist)">Template:Zh</a>), although the country's official name has been changed numerous times by successive <a href="/wiki/Dynasties" title="Dynasties" class="mw-redirect">dynasties</a> and modern governments. The term <i>Zhōngguó</i> appeared in various ancient texts, such as the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Classic_of_History&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Classic of History (page does not exist)">Classic of History</a></i> of the 6th century BCE,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> and in pre-imperial times it was often used as a cultural concept to distinguish the <a href="/wiki/Huaxia" title="Huaxia">Huaxia</a> tribes from perceived "barbarians". The term, which can be either singular or plural, referred to the group of states or provinces in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Plain_(China)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Plain (China) (page does not exist)">central plain</a>, but was not used as a name for the country as a whole until the nineteenth century.  The Chinese were not unique in regarding their country as "central", with other civilizations having the same view of themselves.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>

<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Terracotta_pmorgan.jpg" title="File:Terracotta pmorgan.jpg">File:Terracotta pmorgan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Some of the thousands of life-size <a href="/wiki/Terracotta_Army" title="Terracotta Army">Terracotta Warriors</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Qin_Dynasty" title="Qin Dynasty">Qin Dynasty</a>, ca. 210 BCE</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Archaeological evidence suggests that early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hominidae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hominidae (page does not exist)">hominids</a> inhabited China between 250,000 and 2.24 million years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> A cave in <a href="/wiki/Zhoukoudian" title="Zhoukoudian">Zhoukoudian</a> (near present-day Beijing) exhibits hominid fossils dated at between 680,000 and 780,000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated198_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated198-23">[23]</a></sup> The fossils are of <a href="/wiki/Peking_Man" title="Peking Man">Peking Man</a>, an example of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Homo_erectus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Homo erectus (page does not exist)">Homo erectus</a></i> who <a href="/w/index.php?title=Control_of_fire_by_early_humans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Control of fire by early humans (page does not exist)">used fire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> The Peking Man site has also yielded remains of <i>Homo sapiens</i> dating back to 18,000–11,000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> Some scholars assert that a form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Proto-writing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Proto-writing (page does not exist)">proto-writing</a> existed in China as early as 3000 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Chinese tradition, the first imperial dynasty was the <a href="/wiki/Xia_Dynasty" title="Xia Dynasty">Xia</a>, which emerged around 2070 BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> However, the dynasty was considered mythical by historians until scientific excavations found early <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> sites at <a href="/wiki/Erlitou_culture" title="Erlitou culture">Erlitou</a>, Henan in 1959.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> It remains unclear whether these sites are the remains of the Xia Dynasty or of another culture from the same period.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_dynastic_rule">Early dynastic rule</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The first Chinese dynasty that left historical records, the loosely feudal <a href="/wiki/Shang_Dynasty" title="Shang Dynasty">Shang</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> settled along the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> in eastern China from the 17th to the 11th century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Oracle_bone_script" title="Oracle bone script">oracle bone script</a> of the Shang Dynasty represents the oldest form of Chinese writing yet found,<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> and is a direct ancestor of modern <a href="/wiki/Chinese_characters" title="Chinese characters">Chinese characters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The Shang were conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Dynasty" title="Zhou Dynasty">Zhou</a>, who ruled between the 12th and 5th centuries BCE, until its centralized authority was slowly eroded by feudal warlords. Many independent states eventually emerged from the weakened Zhou state and continually waged war with each other in the 300-year <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spring_and_Autumn_Period&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spring and Autumn Period (page does not exist)">Spring and Autumn Period</a>, only occasionally deferring to the Zhou king. By the time of the <a href="/wiki/Warring_States_period" title="Warring States period">Warring States period</a> of the 5th–3rd centuries BCE, there were seven powerful sovereign states in what is now China, each with its own king, ministry and army.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperial_China">Imperial China</span></h3>
<p>The Warring States period ended in 221 BCE, after the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Qin" title="State of Qin" class="mw-redirect">state of Qin</a> conquered the other six kingdoms and established the first unified Chinese state. <a href="/wiki/Qin_Shi_Huang" title="Qin Shi Huang">Qin Shi Huang</a>, the emperor of Qin, proclaimed himself the "First Emperor" (始皇帝) and imposed reforms throughout China, notably the forced standardization of the Chinese language, measurements, length of cart axles, and currency. The <a href="/wiki/Qin_Dynasty" title="Qin Dynasty">Qin Dynasty</a> lasted only fifteen years, falling soon after Qin Shi Huang's death, as its harsh <a href="/w/index.php?title=Legalism_(philosophy)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Legalism (philosophy) (page does not exist)">legalist</a> and authoritarian policies led to widespread rebellion.<sup id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-35">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chinesische-mauer.jpg" title="File:Chinesische-mauer.jpg">File:Chinesische-mauer.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Wall_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Wall of China (page does not exist)">Great Wall of China</a> was built by several dynasties over two thousand years to protect the sedentary agricultural regions of the <a href="/wiki/China_Proper" title="China Proper" class="mw-redirect">Chinese interior</a> from incursions by <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pastoralists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pastoralists (page does not exist)">pastoralists</a> of the northern <a href="/wiki/Steppes" title="Steppes" class="mw-redirect">steppes</a></div></div></div>
<p>The subsequent <a href="/wiki/Han_Dynasty" title="Han Dynasty">Han Dynasty</a> ruled China between 206 BCE and 220 CE, and created a lasting <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han cultural identity</a> among its populace that has endured to the present day.<sup id="cite_ref-Bodde1986_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bodde1986-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lewis2007_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lewis2007-35">[35]</a></sup> The Han Dynasty <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Han_Dynasty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the Han Dynasty (page does not exist)">expanded the empire's territory considerably</a> with military campaigns reaching Korea, Vietnam, Mongolia and Central Asia, and also helped establish the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a> in Central Asia. Han China gradually became the largest economy of the ancient world.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The Han Dynasty adopted <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>, a philosophy developed in the Spring and Autumn period, as its official state ideology. Despite the Han's official abandonment of Legalism, the official ideology of the Qin, Legalist institutions and policies remained and formed the basis of the Han government.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/w/index.php?title=End_of_the_Han_Dynasty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="End of the Han Dynasty (page does not exist)">collapse of Han</a>, a period of disunion known as the period of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms" title="Three Kingdoms">Three Kingdoms</a> followed.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> In 581 CE, China was reunited under the <a href="/wiki/Sui_Dynasty" title="Sui Dynasty">Sui</a>. However, the Sui Dynasty declined following its defeat in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goguryeo–Sui War (page does not exist)">Goguryeo–Sui War</a> (598–614).<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under the succeeding <a href="/wiki/Tang_Dynasty" title="Tang Dynasty">Tang</a> and <a href="/wiki/Song_Dynasty" title="Song Dynasty">Song</a> dynasties, Chinese technology and culture entered a golden age.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> The Tang Empire was at its height of power until the middle of the 8th century, when the <a href="/w/index.php?title=An_Shi_Rebellion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="An Shi Rebellion (page does not exist)">An Shi Rebellion</a> destroyed the prosperity of the empire.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> The Song Dynasty was the first government in world history to issue paper money and the first Chinese <a href="/wiki/Polity" title="Polity">polity</a> to establish a permanent standing navy.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> Between the 10th and 11th centuries, the population of China doubled in size to around 100 million people, mostly due to the expansion of rice cultivation in central and southern China, and the production of abundant food surpluses. The Song Dynasty also saw a flourishing of philosophy and the arts, as <a href="/wiki/Landscape_art" title="Landscape art">landscape art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portrait</a> painting were brought to new levels of maturity and complexity,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> and social elites gathered to view art, share their own and trade precious artworks. The Song Dynasty saw a <a href="/wiki/Neo-Confucianism" title="Neo-Confucianism">revival of Confucianism</a>, in response to the growth of Buddhism during the Tang.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival_(detail_of_original).jpg" title="File:Along the River During the Qingming Festival (detail of original).jpg">File:Along the River During the Qingming Festival (detail of original).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Detail from <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Along_the_River_During_the_Qingming_Festival&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Along the River During the Qingming Festival (page does not exist)">Along the River During the Qingming Festival</a></i>, a 12th-century painting showing everyday life in the <a href="/wiki/Song_Dynasty" title="Song Dynasty">Song Dynasty</a>'s capital city, Bianjing (today's <a href="/wiki/Kaifeng" title="Kaifeng">Kaifeng</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>In the 13th century, China was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mongol_invasion_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mongol invasion of China (page does not exist)">gradually conquered by the Mongol empire</a>. In 1271, the <a href="/wiki/Mongol" title="Mongol" class="mw-redirect">Mongol</a> leader <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kublai_Khan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kublai Khan (page does not exist)">Kublai Khan</a> established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yuan_Dynasty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yuan Dynasty (page does not exist)">Yuan Dynasty</a>; the Yuan conquered the last remnant of the Song Dynasty in 1279. A peasant named <a href="/wiki/Zhu_Yuanzhang" title="Zhu Yuanzhang" class="mw-redirect">Zhu Yuanzhang</a> overthrew the Yuan Dynasty in 1368 and founded the <a href="/wiki/Ming_Dynasty" title="Ming Dynasty">Ming Dynasty</a>.
Under the Ming Dynasty, China enjoyed another golden age, developing one of the strongest navies in the world and a rich and prosperous economy amid a flourishing of art and culture. It was during this period that <a href="/wiki/Zheng_He" title="Zheng He">Zheng He</a> led <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treasure_voyages&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treasure voyages (page does not exist)">explorations throughout the world, reaching as far as Africa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> In the early years of the Ming Dynasty, China's capital was moved from <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> to Beijing. During the Ming Dynasty, philosophers such as <a href="/wiki/Wang_Yangming" title="Wang Yangming">Wang Yangming</a> further critiqued and expanded Neo-Confucianism with concepts of <a href="/wiki/Individualism" title="Individualism">individualism</a> and innate morality.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1644, Beijing was captured by a coalition of rebel forces led by <a href="/wiki/Li_Zicheng" title="Li Zicheng">Li Zicheng</a>, a minor Ming official who led the peasant revolt. The last Ming <a href="/wiki/Chongzhen_Emperor" title="Chongzhen Emperor">Chongzhen Emperor</a> committed suicide when the city fell. The Manchu <a href="/wiki/Qing_Dynasty" title="Qing Dynasty">Qing Dynasty</a> then allied with Ming Dynasty general <a href="/wiki/Wu_Sangui" title="Wu Sangui">Wu Sangui</a> and overthrew Li's short-lived <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shun_Dynasty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shun Dynasty (page does not exist)">Shun Dynasty</a>, and subsequently seized control of Beijing, which became the new capital of the Qing Dynasty.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="End_of_dynastic_rule">End of dynastic rule</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Regaining_the_Provincial_Capital_of_Ruizhou.jpg" title="File:Regaining the Provincial Capital of Ruizhou.jpg">File:Regaining the Provincial Capital of Ruizhou.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A 19th-century painting depicting the <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping Rebellion</a> of 1850–1864</div></div></div>
<p>The Qing Dynasty, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. In the 19th century, the Qing Dynasty experienced Western imperialism following two <a href="/wiki/Opium_Wars" title="Opium Wars">Opium Wars</a> (1839–42 and 1856–60) with Britain. China was forced to sign unequal treaties, pay compensation, allow extraterritoriality for foreign nationals, and cede <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> to the British.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> (1894−95) resulted in Qing China's loss of influence in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, as well as the cession of Taiwan to Japan.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Qing dynasty also began experiencing internal unrest in which millions of people died. In the 1850s and 1860s, the failed <a href="/wiki/Taiping_Rebellion" title="Taiping Rebellion">Taiping Rebellion</a> ravaged southern China. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Timeline_of_late_anti-Qing_Dynasty_rebellions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Timeline of late anti-Qing Dynasty rebellions (page does not exist)">Other major rebellions</a> included the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Punti%E2%80%93Hakka_Clan_Wars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Punti–Hakka Clan Wars (page does not exist)">Punti–Hakka Clan Wars</a> (1855–67), the <a href="/wiki/Nien_Rebellion" title="Nien Rebellion">Nien Rebellion</a> (1851–68), the Miao Rebellion (1854–73), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Panthay_Rebellion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Panthay Rebellion (page does not exist)">Panthay Rebellion</a> (1856–73) and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dungan_revolt_(1862%E2%80%931877)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dungan revolt (1862–1877) (page does not exist)">Dungan revolt</a> (1862–77).
</p><p>In the 19th century, the great <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Diaspora" title="Chinese Diaspora" class="mw-redirect">Chinese Diaspora</a> began. Emigration rates were strengthened by conflicts and catastrophes such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Chinese_Famine_of_1876%E2%80%931879&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–1879 (page does not exist)">Northern Chinese Famine of 1876–1879</a>, which claimed between 9 and 13 million lives in northern China.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> In 1898, the <a href="/wiki/Guangxu_Emperor" title="Guangxu Emperor">Guangxu Emperor</a> drafted a <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Days%27_Reform" title="Hundred Days' Reform">reform plan</a> to establish a modern <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, but he was overthrown by the <a href="/wiki/Empress_Dowager_Cixi" title="Empress Dowager Cixi">Empress Dowager Cixi</a> in a coup d'état. The ill-fated anti-Western <a href="/wiki/Boxer_Rebellion" title="Boxer Rebellion">Boxer Rebellion</a> of 1899–1901 further weakened the Qing Dynasty. The <a href="/wiki/Xinhai_Revolution" title="Xinhai Revolution">Xinhai Revolution</a> of 1911–12 brought an end to the Qing Dynasty and established the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Republic of China (page does not exist)">Republic of China</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Republic_of_China_.281912.E2.80.931949.29">Republic of China (1912–1949)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sun_Yat-sen_and_Chiang_Kai-shek.jpg" title="File:Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek.jpg">File:Sun Yat-sen and Chiang Kai-shek.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a>, the father of modern China (seated on right), and <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, later <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="President of the Republic of China">President of the Republic of China</a></div></div></div>
<p>On 1 January 1912, the Republic of China was established, and <a href="/wiki/Sun_Yat-sen" title="Sun Yat-sen">Sun Yat-sen</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kuomintang" title="Kuomintang">Kuomintang</a> (the KMT or Nationalist Party) was proclaimed provisional president.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> However, the presidency was later given to <a href="/wiki/Yuan_Shikai" title="Yuan Shikai">Yuan Shikai</a>, a former Qing general, who in 1915 proclaimed himself <a href="/w/index.php?title=Empire_of_China_(1915%E2%80%931916)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Empire of China (1915–1916) (page does not exist)">Emperor of China</a>. In the face of popular condemnation and opposition from his own <a href="/wiki/Beiyang_Army" title="Beiyang Army">Beiyang Army</a>, he was forced to abdicate and reestablish the republic.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Yuan Shikai's death in 1916, China was politically fragmented. Its Beijing-based government was internationally recognized but virtually powerless; regional warlords controlled most of its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> In the late 1920s, the Kuomintang, under <a href="/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek" title="Chiang Kai-shek">Chiang Kai-shek</a>, was able to reunify the country under its own control with a series of deft military and political maneuverings, known collectively as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Expedition" title="Northern Expedition">Northern Expedition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> The Kuomintang moved the nation's capital to <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a> and implemented "political tutelage", an intermediate stage of political development outlined in Sun Yat-sen's <a href="/w/index.php?title=San-min_Doctrine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="San-min Doctrine (page does not exist)">San-min</a> program for transforming China into a modern democratic state.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_warlords_and_military_cliques_in_the_Warlord_Era&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of warlords and military cliques in the Warlord Era (page does not exist)">political division</a> in China made it difficult for Chiang to battle the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communists" title="Chinese Communists" class="mw-redirect">Communists</a>, against whom the Kuomintang had been warring since 1927 in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a>. This war continued successfully for the Kuomintang, especially after the Communists retreated in the <a href="/wiki/Long_March" title="Long March">Long March</a>, until Japanese aggression and the 1936 <a href="/wiki/Xi%27an_Incident" title="Xi'an Incident">Xi'an Incident</a> forced Chiang to confront <a href="/w/index.php?title=Imperial_Japan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Imperial Japan (page does not exist)">Imperial Japan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Second_Sino-Japanese_War" title="Second Sino-Japanese War">Second Sino-Japanese War</a> (1937–1945), a theater of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, forced an uneasy alliance between the Kuomintang and the Communists. Japanese forces committed numerous <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">war atrocities</a> against the civilian population; in all, as many as 20 million Chinese civilians died.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> An estimated 200,000 Chinese <a href="/wiki/Nanking_Massacre" title="Nanking Massacre">were massacred</a> in the city of Nanjing alone during the Japanese occupation.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Japan unconditionally surrendered to China in 1945. Taiwan, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pescadores&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pescadores (page does not exist)">Pescadores</a>, was put under the administrative control of the Republic of China, which immediately claimed sovereignty. China emerged victorious but war-ravaged and financially drained. The continued distrust between the Kuomintang and the Communists led to the resumption of civil war. In 1947, constitutional rule was established, but because of the ongoing unrest many provisions of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the Republic of China">ROC constitution</a> were never implemented in mainland China.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="People.27s_Republic_of_China_.281949.E2.80.93present.29">People's Republic of China (1949–present)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:China,_Mao_(2).jpg" title="File:China, Mao (2).jpg">File:China, Mao (2).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaiming the establishment of the PRC in 1949</div></div></div>
<p>Major combat in the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> ended in 1949 with the Communist Party in control of most of <a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>, and the Kuomintang retreating offshore, reducing the ROC's territory to only <a href="/wiki/Taiwan_(island)" title="Taiwan (island)" class="mw-redirect">Taiwan</a>, Hainan, their surrounding islands. On 1 October 1949, <a href="/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="Chairman of the Communist Party of China">Communist Party Chairman</a> <a href="/wiki/Mao_Zedong" title="Mao Zedong">Mao Zedong</a> proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_c_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_c-63">[63]</a></sup> In 1950, the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People's Liberation Army">People's Liberation Army</a> succeeded in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Landing_Operation_on_Hainan_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Landing Operation on Hainan Island (page does not exist)">capturing Hainan</a> from the ROC<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> and occupying <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> However, remaining Nationalist forces continued to wage <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kuomintang_Islamic_insurgency_in_China_(1950%E2%80%9358)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kuomintang Islamic insurgency in China (1950–58) (page does not exist)">an insurgency in western China</a> throughout the 1950s.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mao encouraged population growth, and under his leadership the Chinese population almost doubled from around 550 million to over 900 million.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> However, Mao's <a href="/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward" title="Great Leap Forward">Great Leap Forward</a>, a large-scale economic and social reform project, resulted in <a href="/wiki/Great_Chinese_Famine" title="Great Chinese Famine">an estimated 45&#160;million deaths</a> between 1958 and 1961, mostly from starvation.<sup id="cite_ref-Akbar2010_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Akbar2010-68">[68]</a></sup> Between 1 and 2 million <a href="/wiki/Landlord" title="Landlord">landlords</a> were executed as "counterrevolutionaries."<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In 1966, Mao and his allies launched the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, sparking a period of political recrimination and social upheaval which lasted until Mao's death in 1976. In October 1971, the PRC <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_2758" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758">replaced the Republic of China</a> in the United Nations, and took its seat as a permanent member of the Security Council.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Mao's death in 1976 and the arrest of the faction known as the <a href="/wiki/Gang_of_Four" title="Gang of Four">Gang of Four</a>, who were blamed for the excesses of the Cultural Revolution, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> took power and led the country to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_economic_reform&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese economic reform (page does not exist)">significant economic reforms</a>. The Communist Party subsequently loosened governmental control over citizens' personal lives and the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_commune" title="People's commune">communes</a> were disbanded in favor of private land leases. This turn of events marked China's transition from a planned economy to a mixed economy with an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics (page does not exist)">increasingly open market environment</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_e_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_e-71">[71]</a></sup> China adopted its current <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">constitution</a> on 4 December 1982. In 1989, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=People%27s_Liberation_Army_at_Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="People's Liberation Army at Tiananmen Square protests of 1989 (page does not exist)">violent suppression</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">student protests in Tiananmen Square</a> brought condemnation and sanctions against the Chinese government from various countries.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Flickr_-_Shinrya_-_Shanghai_Skyline_HDR.jpg" title="File:Flickr - Shinrya - Shanghai Skyline HDR.jpg">File:Flickr - Shinrya - Shanghai Skyline HDR.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> skyline</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Jiang_Zemin" title="Jiang Zemin">Jiang Zemin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premier</a> <a href="/wiki/Zhu_Rongji" title="Zhu Rongji">Zhu Rongji</a> led the nation in the 1990s. Under their administration, China's economic performance pulled an estimated 150&#160;million peasants out of poverty and sustained an average annual gross domestic product growth rate of 11.2%.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_h_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_h-73">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_i_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_i-74">[74]</a></sup> The country formally joined the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> in 2001, and maintained its high rate of economic growth under <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a>'s presidency in the 2000s. However, rapid growth also severely impacted the country's resources and environment,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_j_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_j-76">[76]</a></sup> and caused <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protest_and_dissent_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protest and dissent in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">major social displacement</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_k_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_k-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_l_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_l-78">[78]</a></sup> Living standards continued to improve rapidly despite the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Late-2000s_recession&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Late-2000s recession (page does not exist)">late-2000s recession</a>, but centralized political control remained tight.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Preparations for a decadal Communist Party leadership change in 2012 were marked by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wang_Lijun_incident&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wang Lijun incident (page does not exist)">factional disputes and political scandals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> During China's <a href="/w/index.php?title=18th_National_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="18th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (page does not exist)">18th National Communist Party Congress</a> in November 2012, Hu Jintao and <a href="/wiki/Wen_Jiabao" title="Wen Jiabao">Wen Jiabao</a> were replaced as President and Premier by <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> and <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, who formally took office in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-XiJinpingLiKeqiang_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XiJinpingLiKeqiang-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Under Xi, the Chinese government began large-scale efforts to reform its economy,<sup id="cite_ref-BBC19July2013a_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC19July2013a-83">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> which has suffered from structural instabilities and slowing growth.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9Dec2012_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9Dec2012-86">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> Xi's administration also announced major reforms to the <a href="/wiki/One-child_policy" title="One-child policy">one-child policy</a> and prison system.<sup id="cite_ref-SlateChina2013_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlateChina2013-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_geography">Political geography</span></h3>
<p>The People's Republic of China is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_land_area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries and outlying territories by land area (page does not exist)">second-largest</a> country in the world by land area<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> after <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, and is either the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area" class="mw-redirect">third- or fourth-largest</a> by total area, after Russia, Canada and, depending on the definition of total area, the United States.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> China's total area is generally stated as being approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>  Specific area figures range from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> according to the <i><a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-archive_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-archive-92">[92]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> according to the UN Demographic Yearbook,<sup id="cite_ref-UN_Stat_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN_Stat-93">[93]</a></sup> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook" class="mw-redirect">CIA World Factbook</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_land_border_lengths&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of land border lengths (page does not exist)">longest combined land border in the world</a>, measuring  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> from the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Yalu_River" title="Yalu River">Yalu River</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Tonkin" title="Gulf of Tonkin">Gulf of Tonkin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-94">[94]</a></sup> China <a href="/w/index.php?title=Borders_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Borders of China (page does not exist)">borders 14 nations</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_number_of_neighbouring_countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by number of neighbouring countries (page does not exist)">more than any other country</a> except Russia, which also borders 14.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>  China extends across much of East Asia, bordering <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Burma" title="Burma">Burma</a> in Southeast Asia; <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhutan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bhutan (page does not exist)">Bhutan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> in South Asia; <a href="/wiki/Afghanistan" title="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> in Central Asia; and <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> in <a href="/wiki/Inner_Asia" title="Inner Asia">Inner Asia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Asia" title="Northeast Asia">Northeast Asia</a>. Additionally, China shares maritime boundaries with <a href="/wiki/South_Korea" title="South Korea">South Korea</a>, Japan, Vietnam, the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a> and Taiwan.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Landscape_and_climate">Landscape and climate</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
</p><p>The territory of China lies between <a href="/wiki/Latitude" title="Latitude">latitudes</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=18th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="18th parallel north (page does not exist)">18°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=54th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="54th parallel north (page does not exist)">54° N</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitudes</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=73rd_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="73rd meridian east (page does not exist)">73°</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=135th_meridian_east&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="135th meridian east (page does not exist)">135° E</a>. China's landscapes vary significantly across its vast width. In the east, along the shores of the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>, there are extensive and densely populated <a href="/wiki/Alluvium" title="Alluvium">alluvial plains</a>, while on the edges of the Inner Mongolian plateau in the north, broad <a href="/wiki/Grassland" title="Grassland">grasslands</a> predominate. Southern China is dominated by hills and low mountain ranges, while the central-east hosts the <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">deltas</a> of China's two major rivers, the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_River" title="Yellow River">Yellow River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a>. Other major rivers include the <a href="/wiki/Xi_River" title="Xi River">Xi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mekong" title="Mekong">Mekong</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahmaputra_River" title="Brahmaputra River">Brahmaputra</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur</a>. To the west sit major mountain ranges, most notably the Himalayas. High <a href="/wiki/Plateau" title="Plateau">plateaus</a> feature among the more arid landscapes of the north, such as the <a href="/wiki/Taklamakan_Desert" title="Taklamakan Desert">Taklamakan</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gobi_Desert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gobi Desert (page does not exist)">Gobi Desert</a>. The world's highest point, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Everest" title="Mount Everest">Mount Everest</a> (8,848m), lies on the Sino-Nepalese border.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> The country's lowest point, and the world's third-lowest, is the dried lake bed of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ayding_Lake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ayding Lake (page does not exist)">Ayding Lake</a> (−154m) in the <a href="/wiki/Turpan_Depression" title="Turpan Depression">Turpan Depression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's climate is mainly dominated by <a href="/wiki/Dry_season" title="Dry season">dry seasons</a> and wet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Monsoons&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Monsoons (page does not exist)">monsoons</a>, which lead to pronounced temperature differences between winter and summer. In the winter, northern winds coming from high-latitude areas are cold and dry; in summer, southern winds from coastal areas at lower latitudes are warm and moist.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> The climate in China differs from region to region because of the country's highly complex <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a>.
</p><p>A major environmental issue in China is the continued <a href="/wiki/Desertification" title="Desertification">expansion of its deserts</a>, particularly the Gobi Desert.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_au_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_au-100">[100]</a></sup> Although barrier tree lines planted since the 1970s have reduced the frequency of <a href="/wiki/Sandstorms" title="Sandstorms" class="mw-redirect">sandstorms</a>, prolonged drought and poor agricultural practices have resulted in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Asian_dust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Asian dust (page does not exist)">dust storms</a> plaguing northern China each spring, which then spread to other parts of East Asia, including Korea and Japan. According to China's environmental watchdog, Sepa, China is losing a million acres (4,000&#160;km²) per year to desertification.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_av_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_av-101">[101]</a></sup> Water quality, <a href="/wiki/Erosion" title="Erosion">erosion</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pollution_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pollution in China (page does not exist)">pollution control</a> have become important issues in China's relations with other countries. Melting <a href="/wiki/Glaciers" title="Glaciers" class="mw-redirect">glaciers</a> in the Himalayas could potentially lead to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Water_shortage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Water shortage (page does not exist)">water shortages</a> for hundreds of millions of people.<sup id="cite_ref-msnbc_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-msnbc-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Panda_Cub_from_Wolong,_Sichuan,_China.JPG" title="File:Panda Cub from Wolong, Sichuan, China.JPG">File:Panda Cub from Wolong, Sichuan, China.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/Giant_panda" title="Giant panda">giant panda</a>, China's most famous <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of endangered and protected species of China (page does not exist)">endangered</a> and <a href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic" class="mw-redirect">endemic</a> species, at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wolong_National_Nature_Reserve&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wolong National Nature Reserve (page does not exist)">Wolong National Nature Reserve</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a></div></div></div>
<p>China is one of 17 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Megadiverse_countries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Megadiverse countries (page does not exist)">megadiverse countries</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009a_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009a-103">[103]</a></sup> lying in two of the world's major <a href="/wiki/Ecozone" title="Ecozone">ecozones</a>: the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Palearctic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Palearctic (page does not exist)">Palearctic</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indomalaya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indomalaya (page does not exist)">Indomalaya</a>. By one measure, China has over 34,687 species of animals and vascular plants, making it the third-most biodiverse country in the world, after <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> The country signed the <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 11 June 1992, and became a party to the convention on 5 January 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> It later produced a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biodiversity_action_plan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biodiversity action plan (page does not exist)">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>, with one revision that was received by the convention on 21 September 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>China is home to at least 551 species of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_mammals_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of mammals of China (page does not exist)">mammals</a> (the third-highest such number in the world),<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> 1,221 species of birds (eighth),<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> 424 species of reptiles (seventh)<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> and 333 species of amphibians (seventh).<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> China is the most biodiverse country in each category outside of the tropics. Wildlife in China share habitat with and bear acute pressure from the world's largest population of <i><a href="/wiki/Homo_sapiens" title="Homo sapiens">homo sapiens</a></i>. At least 840 <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_endangered_and_protected_species_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of endangered and protected species of China (page does not exist)">animal species are threatened, vulnerable or in danger of local extinction</a> in China, due mainly to human activity such as habitat destruction, pollution and poaching for food, fur and ingredients for <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine" title="Traditional Chinese medicine">traditional Chinese medicine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> Endangered wildlife is protected by law, and as of 2005, the country has over 2,349 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protected_areas_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protected areas of China (page does not exist)">nature reserves</a>, covering a total area of 149.95 million hectares, 15 percent of China's total land area.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has over 32,000 species of vascular plants,<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> and is home to a variety of forest types. Cold <a href="/wiki/Coniferous" title="Coniferous" class="mw-redirect">coniferous</a> forests predominate in the north of the country, supporting animal species such as <a href="/wiki/Moose" title="Moose">moose</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asian_black_bear" title="Asian black bear">Asian black bear</a>, along with over 120 bird species.<sup id="cite_ref-rough_guide_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-114">[114]</a></sup> The understorey of moist <a href="/wiki/Conifer" title="Conifer" class="mw-redirect">conifer</a> forests may contain thickets of <a href="/wiki/Bamboo" title="Bamboo">bamboo</a>. In higher montane stands of <a href="/wiki/Juniper" title="Juniper">juniper</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taxus" title="Taxus">yew</a>, the bamboo is replaced by <a href="/wiki/Rhododendron" title="Rhododendron">rhododendrons</a>. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Subtropical&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Subtropical (page does not exist)">Subtropical</a> forests, which are predominate in central and southern China, support as many as 146,000 species of flora.<sup id="cite_ref-rough_guide_114-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-114">[114]</a></sup> Tropical and seasonal <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a>, though confined to <a href="/wiki/Yunnan" title="Yunnan">Yunnan</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hainan_Island&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hainan Island (page does not exist)">Hainan Island</a>, contain a quarter of all the animal and plant species found in China.<sup id="cite_ref-rough_guide_114-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rough_guide-114">[114]</a></sup> China has over 10,000 recorded species of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fungi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fungi (page does not exist)">fungi</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> and of them, nearly 6,000 are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Higher_fungi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Higher fungi (page does not exist)">higher fungi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_issues">Environmental issues</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Wind_power_plants_in_Xinjiang,_China.jpg" title="File:Wind power plants in Xinjiang, China.jpg">File:Wind power plants in Xinjiang, China.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Wind_turbine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wind turbine (page does not exist)">Wind turbines</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xinjiang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xinjiang (page does not exist)">Xinjiang</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dabancheng&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dabancheng (page does not exist)">Dabancheng</a> project is Asia's largest <a href="/wiki/Wind_farm" title="Wind farm">wind farm</a></div></div></div>
<p>In recent decades, China has suffered from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_issues_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental issues in China (page does not exist)">severe environmental deterioration and pollution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ma2002_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ma2002-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> While regulations such as the 1979 Environmental Protection Law are fairly stringent, they are poorly enforced, as they are frequently disregarded by local communities and government officials in favor of rapid economic development.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Urban air pollution is a severe health issue in the country; the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> estimated in 2013 that 16 of the world's 20 most-polluted cities are located in China.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> China is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> emitter.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> The country also has water problems. Roughly 298&#160;million Chinese in rural areas do not have access to safe drinking water,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> and 40% of China's rivers had been polluted by industrial and agricultural waste by late 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> This crisis is compounded by increasingly severe water shortages, particularly in the north-east of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Desalination_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Desalination-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2004_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2004-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, China is the world's leading investor in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Renewable_energy_commercialization&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Renewable energy commercialization (page does not exist)">renewable energy commercialization</a>, with <a href="/wiki/US$" title="US$" class="mw-redirect">$</a>52&#160;billion invested in 2011 alone;<sup id="cite_ref-By2010_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-By2010-126">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Black2010_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Black2010-127">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ChinaLeadingEnergy_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaLeadingEnergy-128">[128]</a></sup> it is a major manufacturer of renewable energy technologies and invests heavily in local-scale renewable energy projects.<sup id="cite_ref-bradsher_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bradsher-129">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> By 2009, over 17% of China's energy was derived from renewable sources – most notably <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power" title="Hydroelectric power" class="mw-redirect">hydroelectric power</a> plants, of which China has a total installed capacity of 197 GW.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> In 2011, the Chinese government announced plans to invest four trillion yuan (US$618.55 billion) in water infrastructure and <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a> projects over a ten-year period, and to complete construction of a flood prevention and anti-drought system by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-Desalination_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Desalination-124">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> In 2013, China began a five-year, US$277 billion effort to reduce air pollution, particularly in the north of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The People's Republic of China is one of the world's few remaining <a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialist_state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Socialist state (page does not exist)">socialist states openly endorsing communism</a>. The Chinese government has been variously described as communist and socialist, but also as authoritarian and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Corporatism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Corporatism (page does not exist)">corporatist</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> with heavy restrictions in many areas, most notably against <a href="/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Internet censorship in the People's Republic of China">free access to the Internet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">freedom of assembly</a>, <a href="/wiki/Reproductive_rights" title="Reproductive rights">the right to have children</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=NGO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NGO (page does not exist)">free formation of social organizations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-135">[135]</a></sup> Its current political and economic system has been termed by its leaders as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Socialism_with_Chinese_characteristics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Socialism with Chinese characteristics (page does not exist)">socialism with Chinese characteristics</a>" (which is <a href="/wiki/Marxism" title="Marxism">Marxism</a> adapted to Chinese circumstances) and as the "<a href="/wiki/Socialist_market_economy" title="Socialist market economy">socialist market economy</a>" respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>The country is ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_China" title="Communist Party of China">Communist Party of China</a> (CPC), whose power is enshrined in <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">China's constitution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Elections in the People's Republic of China">Chinese electoral system</a> is hierarchical, whereby local People's Congresses are <a href="/wiki/Direct_election" title="Direct election">directly elected</a>, and all higher levels of People's Congresses up to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_People%27s_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National People's Congress (page does not exist)">National People's Congress</a> (NPC) are <a href="/wiki/Indirect_election" title="Indirect election">indirectly elected</a> by the People's Congress of the level immediately below.<sup id="cite_ref-a97_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-a97-138">[138]</a></sup> The political system is decentralized, and provincial and sub-provincial leaders have a significant amount of autonomy.<sup id="cite_ref-cfr_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cfr-139">[139]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="List of political parties in the People's Republic of China">other political parties in China</a>, referred to in China as democratic parties, which participate in the National People's Congress and the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_People%27s_Political_Consultative_Conference" title="Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference">Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference</a> (CPPCC).<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Great_Hall_Of_The_People_At_Night.JPG" title="File:Great Hall Of The People At Night.JPG">File:Great Hall Of The People At Night.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Great_Hall_of_the_People" title="Great Hall of the People">Great Hall of the People</a> in Beijing, where the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_People%27s_Congress&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National People's Congress (page does not exist)">National People's Congress</a> convenes</div></div></div>
<p>Compared to its closed-door policies until the mid-1970s, the liberalization of China has resulted in the administrative climate being less restrictive than before.
