China supports the Leninist principle of "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_centralism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic centralism (page does not exist)">democratic centralism</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> but the elected National People's Congress has been described as a "<a href="/wiki/Rubber_stamp_(politics)" title="Rubber stamp (politics)">rubber stamp</a>" body.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> The incumbent <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="President of the People's Republic of China">President</a> is <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a>, who is also the <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_China" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of China">General Secretary of the Communist Party of China</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chairman_of_the_Central_Military_Commission&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chairman of the Central Military Commission (page does not exist)">Chairman</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Central_Military_Commission_(China)" title="Central Military Commission (China)">Central Military Commission</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-XiJinpingLiKeqiang_81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XiJinpingLiKeqiang-81">[81]</a></sup> The current <a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Premier of the People's Republic of China">Premier</a> is <a href="/wiki/Li_Keqiang" title="Li Keqiang">Li Keqiang</a>, who is also a senior member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=CPC_Politburo_Standing_Committee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CPC Politburo Standing Committee (page does not exist)">CPC Politburo Standing Committee</a>.
</p><p>There have been some moves toward political liberalization, in that open contested elections are now held at the village and town levels.<sup id="cite_ref-poll_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-poll-143">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_p_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_p-144">[144]</a></sup> However, the Party retains effective control over government appointments: in the absence of meaningful opposition, the CPC wins by default most of the time. Political concerns in China include the growing gap between rich and poor and government corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_q_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_q-145">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> Nonetheless, the level of public support for the government and its management of the nation is high, with 80–95% of Chinese citizens expressing satisfaction with the central government, according to a 2011 survey.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The People's Republic of China has administrative control over 22 <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_China" title="Provinces of China">provinces</a> and considers <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> to be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">its 23rd province</a>, although <a href="/w/index.php?title=Taiwan_Province,_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">Taiwan</a> is currently and independently governed by the Republic of China, which disputes the PRC's claim.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_ap_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ap-148">[148]</a></sup> China also has five subdivisions officially termed <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_regions_of_China" title="Autonomous regions of China">autonomous regions</a>, each with a designated minority group; four <a href="/w/index.php?title=Direct-controlled_municipality_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Direct-controlled municipality of China (page does not exist)">municipalities</a>; and two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Special_Administrative_Region&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Special Administrative Region (page does not exist)">Special Administrative Regions</a> (SARs), which enjoy a degree of political autonomy. These 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, and four municipalities can be collectively referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Mainland_China" title="Mainland China">mainland China</a>", a term which usually excludes the SARs of <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Macau" title="Macau">Macau</a>.  None of these divisions are recognized by the ROC government, which claims the entirety of the PRC's territory.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:PRC_provinces_small_imagemap/province_list&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:PRC provinces small imagemap/province list (page does not exist)">Template:PRC provinces small imagemap/province list</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:PRC_provinces_big_imagemap_alt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:PRC provinces big imagemap alt (page does not exist)">Template:PRC provinces big imagemap alt</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leon_Panetta_and_Xi_Jinping_in_Beijing,_Sept._19,_2012.jpg" title="File:Leon Panetta and Xi Jinping in Beijing, Sept. 19, 2012.jpg">File:Leon Panetta and Xi Jinping in Beijing, Sept. 19, 2012.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Xi Jinping at a meeting with <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">United States Secretary of Defense</a> <a href="/wiki/Leon_Panetta" title="Leon Panetta">Leon Panetta</a> in September 2012.</div></div></div>
<p>The PRC has diplomatic relations with 171 countries and maintains <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of diplomatic missions of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">embassies in 162</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Legitimacy_(political)" title="Legitimacy (political)">legitimacy</a> is disputed by the Republic of China and a few other countries; it is thus the largest and most populous <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_limited_recognition" title="List of states with limited recognition">state with limited recognition</a>. In 1971, the PRC replaced the Republic of China as the sole representative of China in the United Nations and as one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_r_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_r-150">[150]</a></sup> China was also a former member and leader of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, and still considers itself an advocate for <a href="/wiki/Developing_countries" title="Developing countries" class="mw-redirect">developing countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009-151">[151]</a></sup> Along with Brazil, Russia, India and South Africa, China is a member of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BRICS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BRICS (page does not exist)">BRICS</a> group of emerging major economies and hosted the group's <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_BRICS_summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 BRICS summit (page does not exist)">third official summit</a> at <a href="/wiki/Sanya" title="Sanya">Sanya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hainan" title="Hainan">Hainan</a> in April 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under its interpretation of the <a href="/wiki/One-China_policy" title="One-China policy">One-China policy</a>, Beijing has made it a precondition to establishing diplomatic relations that the other country acknowledges its claim to Taiwan and severs official ties with the government of the Republic of China. Chinese officials have protested on numerous occasions when foreign countries have made diplomatic overtures to Taiwan,<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> especially in the matter of armament sales.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> Political meetings between foreign government officials and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=14th_Dalai_Lama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="14th Dalai Lama (page does not exist)">14th Dalai Lama</a> are also opposed by China, as the latter considers Tibet to be formally part of China.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of current Chinese foreign policy is reportedly based on <a href="/wiki/Zhou_Enlai" title="Zhou Enlai">Zhou Enlai</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Five_Principles_of_Peaceful_Coexistence" title="Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence">Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence</a>, and is also driven by the concept of "harmony without uniformity", which encourages diplomatic relations between states despite ideological differences.<sup id="cite_ref-Keith_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Keith-156">[156]</a></sup> This policy may have led China to support states that are <a href="/wiki/Rogue_state" title="Rogue state">regarded as dangerous</a> or repressive by Western nations, such as <a href="/wiki/Zimbabwe" title="Zimbabwe">Zimbabwe</a>, North Korea and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> China has a close economic and military relationship with Russia,<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> and the two states often vote in unison in the UN Security Council.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:G5_meeting_in_Germany.jpg" title="File:G5 meeting in Germany.jpg">File:G5 meeting in Germany.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A meeting of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Group_of_Five&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Group of Five (page does not exist)">G5</a> leaders in 2007, with China's <a href="/wiki/Hu_Jintao" title="Hu Jintao">Hu Jintao</a> second from right</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Trade_relations">Trade relations</span></h4>
<p>In recent decades, China has played an increasing role in calling for <a href="/wiki/Free_trade_area" title="Free trade area">free trade areas</a> and security pacts amongst its Asia-Pacific neighbors. In 2004, it proposed an entirely new <a href="/w/index.php?title=East_Asia_Summit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="East Asia Summit (page does not exist)">East Asia Summit</a> (EAS) framework as a forum for regional security issues.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_s_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_s-162">[162]</a></sup> The EAS, which includes <a href="/w/index.php?title=ASEAN_Plus_Three&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ASEAN Plus Three (page does not exist)">ASEAN Plus Three</a>, India, Australia and New Zealand, held its inaugural summit in 2005. China is also a founding member of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO), along with Russia and the Central Asian republics. China became a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on 11 December 2001.
</p><p>In 2000, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> approved "permanent normal trade relations" (PNTR) with China, allowing Chinese exports in at the same low tariffs as goods from most other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> China has a significant <a href="/wiki/Trade_surplus" title="Trade surplus" class="mw-redirect">trade surplus</a> with the United States, its most important export market.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_w_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_w-164">[164]</a></sup> In the early 2010s, US politicians argued that the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_yuan" title="Chinese yuan">Chinese yuan</a> was significantly undervalued, giving China an unfair trade advantage.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_x_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_x-165">[165]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CurrencyManipulator_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-166">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> In recent decades, China has followed a policy of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Involvement_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China_in_Africa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Involvement of the People's Republic of China in Africa (page does not exist)">engaging with African nations</a> for trade and bilateral co-operation;<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_ae_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ae-168">[168]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_af_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_af-169">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_ag_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ag-170">[170]</a></sup> in 2012, Sino-African trade totalled over US$160 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> China has furthermore strengthened its ties with major South American economies, becoming the largest trading partner of Brazil and building strategic links with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Argentina (page does not exist)">Argentina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Territorial_disputes">Territorial disputes</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:China_administrative.png" title="File:China administrative.png">File:China administrative.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map depicting territorial disputes between the PRC and neighboring states. For a larger map, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:PRC_provinces_big_imagemap&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:PRC provinces big imagemap (page does not exist)">see here.</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
In addition to claiming all of Taiwan, China has been involved in a number of other international territorial disputes. Since the 1990s, China has been involved in negotiations to resolve its disputed land borders, including a <a href="/wiki/Kashmir" title="Kashmir">disputed border with India</a> and an undefined border with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bhutan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bhutan (page does not exist)">Bhutan</a>. China is additionally involved in multilateral disputes over the ownership of several small islands in the East and South China Seas, such as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Senkaku_Islands_dispute&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Senkaku Islands dispute (page does not exist)">Senkaku Islands</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scarborough_Shoal_standoff&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scarborough Shoal standoff (page does not exist)">Scarborough Shoal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Emerging_superpower_status">Emerging superpower status</span></h4>
<p>China is regularly hailed as a potential <a href="/w/index.php?title=China_as_an_emerging_superpower&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China as an emerging superpower (page does not exist)">new superpower</a>, with certain commentators citing its rapid economic progress, growing military might, very large population, and increasing international influence as signs that it will play a prominent global role in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese Century (page does not exist)">21st century</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Others, however, warn that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economic_bubbles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economic bubbles (page does not exist)">economic bubbles</a> and demographic imbalances could slow or even halt China's growth as the century progresses.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup>
Some authors also question the definition of "superpower", arguing that China's large economy alone would not qualify it as a superpower, and noting that it lacks the military and cultural influence of the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sociopolitical_issues_and_reform">Sociopolitical issues and reform</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2010-07-25_Guangzhou_mass_assembly.jpg" title="File:2010-07-25 Guangzhou mass assembly.jpg">File:2010-07-25 Guangzhou mass assembly.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Pro-<a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> protests in Guangzhou, 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_democracy_movement" title="Chinese democracy movement">Chinese democracy movement</a>, social activists, and some members of the Communist Party of China have all identified the need for social and political reform. While economic and social controls have been significantly relaxed in China since the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Political_freedom" title="Political freedom">political freedom</a> is still tightly restricted. The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="Constitution of the People's Republic of China">Constitution of the People's Republic of China</a> states that the "fundamental rights" of citizens include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freedom_of_speech&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freedom of speech (page does not exist)">freedom of speech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Right_to_a_fair_trial" title="Right to a fair trial">right to a fair trial</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Property" title="Property">property rights</a>. However, in practice, these provisions do not afford significant protection against criminal prosecution by the state.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-180">[180]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hrw_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-181">[181]</a></sup> Censorship of political speech and information, most notably on the Internet,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AnonymousNoMore_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AnonymousNoMore-183">[183]</a></sup> is openly and routinely used in China to silence criticism of the government and the ruling <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party" title="Chinese Communist Party" class="mw-redirect">Communist Party</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> In 2005, <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> ranked China 159th out of 167 states in its Annual World Press Freedom Index, indicating a very low level of perceived press freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-rsf.org-554_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rsf.org-554-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rural migrants to China's cities often find themselves treated as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second-class_citizen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second-class citizen (page does not exist)">second-class citizens</a> by the <i>hukou</i> <a href="/wiki/Hukou_system" title="Hukou system">household registration</a> system, which controls access to <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">state benefits</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ruralmillions_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ruralmillions-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hukou_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hukou-188">[188]</a></sup> Property rights are often poorly protected,<sup id="cite_ref-ruralmillions_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ruralmillions-187">[187]</a></sup> and taxation disproportionately affects poorer citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-hukou_188-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hukou-188">[188]</a></sup> However, a number of rural taxes have been reduced or abolished since the early 2000s, and additional social services provided to rural dwellers.<sup id="cite_ref-Ni2005_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ni2005-189">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2006_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2006-190">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of foreign governments, foreign press agencies and <a href="/w/index.php?title=NGO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="NGO (page does not exist)">NGOs</a> also routinely criticize <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_rights_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human rights in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">China's human rights record</a>, alleging widespread <a href="/w/index.php?title=Civil_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Civil rights (page does not exist)">civil rights</a> violations such as detention without trial, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Forced_abortions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forced abortions (page does not exist)">forced abortions</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> forced confessions, <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a>, restrictions of fundamental rights,<sup id="cite_ref-freedomhouse_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedomhouse-135">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ban_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ban-193">[193]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capital_punishment_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capital punishment in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">excessive use of the death penalty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wp_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wp-194">[194]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> The government has suppressed demonstrations by organizations that it considers a potential threat to "social stability", as was the case with the <a href="/wiki/Tiananmen_Square_protests_of_1989" title="Tiananmen Square protests of 1989">Tiananmen Square protests of 1989</a>. The Chinese state is regularly accused of large-scale repression and human rights abuses in <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xinjiang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xinjiang (page does not exist)">Xinjiang</a>, including violent police crackdowns and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Religious_suppression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Religious suppression (page does not exist)">religious suppression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chinese government has responded to foreign criticism by arguing that the notion of human rights should take into account a country's present level of <a href="/wiki/Economic_development" title="Economic development">economic development</a> and the "people's rights to subsistence and development".<sup id="cite_ref-yqlgro_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yqlgro-198">[198]</a></sup> It emphasizes the rise in the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Standard_of_living" title="Standard of living">standard of living</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Literacy_rate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Literacy rate (page does not exist)">literacy rate</a> and average <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> since the 1970s, as well as improvements in workplace safety and efforts to combat natural disasters such as the perennial <a href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a> floods.<sup id="cite_ref-yqlgro_198-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-yqlgro-198">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_ao_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_ao-200">[200]</a></sup> Furthermore, some Chinese politicians have spoken out in support of democratisation, although <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_skepticism_of_democracy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese skepticism of democracy (page does not exist)">others remain more conservative</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> Some major reform efforts have been conducted; for an instance in November 2013, the government announced its plans to the abolish the much-criticized <a href="/wiki/Re-education_through_labor" title="Re-education through labor">re-education through labor</a> program.<sup id="cite_ref-SlateChina2013_89-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SlateChina2013-89">[89]</a></sup> Although during the 2000s and early 2010s, the Chinese government was increasingly tolerant of NGOs that offer practical, efficient solutions to social problems, such "third sector" activity remained heavily regulated.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:J-10a_zhas.png" title="File:J-10a zhas.png">File:J-10a zhas.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">PLAAF</a> <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-10" title="Chengdu J-10">Chengdu J-10</a> fighter aircraft</div></div></div>
<p>With 2.3&#160;million active troops, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is the largest standing military force in the world, commanded by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Central_Military_Commission_(People%27s_Republic_of_China)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Central Military Commission (People's Republic of China) (page does not exist)">Central Military Commission</a> (CMC).<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdep_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdep-203">[203]</a></sup> The PLA consists of the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Ground_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Ground Force">People's Liberation Army Ground Force</a> (PLAGF), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Navy" title="People's Liberation Army Navy">People's Liberation Army Navy</a> (PLAN), the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Air_Force" title="People's Liberation Army Air Force">People's Liberation Army Air Force</a> (PLAAF), and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Strategic_missile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Strategic missile (page does not exist)">strategic</a> nuclear force, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_Artillery_Corps_(China)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second Artillery Corps (China) (page does not exist)">Second Artillery Corps</a>. According to the Chinese government, China's military expenditure in 2012 totalled US$100 billion, constituting the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by military expenditures (page does not exist)">world's second-largest military budget</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> However, other nations, such as the United States, have argued that China does not report its real level of military spending, which is allegedly much higher than the official budget.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeq_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeq-205">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a recognized <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons" title="Nuclear weapons" class="mw-redirect">nuclear weapons</a> state, China is considered both a major regional military power and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Potential_superpowers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Potential superpowers (page does not exist)">potential military superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcder_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcder-206">[206]</a></sup> According to a 2013 report by the <a href="/wiki/US_Department_of_Defense" title="US Department of Defense" class="mw-redirect">US Department of Defense</a>, China fields between 50 and 75 nuclear <a href="/wiki/ICBM" title="ICBM" class="mw-redirect">ICBMs</a>, along with a number of <a href="/wiki/Short-range_ballistic_missile" title="Short-range ballistic missile">SRBMs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ChineseNukes_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChineseNukes-13">[13]</a></sup> However, compared with the other four <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council" title="UN Security Council" class="mw-redirect">UN Security Council</a> Permanent Members, China has a relatively limited <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_power_projection&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military power projection (page does not exist)">power projection</a> capabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-Martin_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Martin-207">[207]</a></sup>  To offset this, it has developed numerous power projection assets – its <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_aircraft_carrier_Liaoning&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese aircraft carrier Liaoning (page does not exist)">first aircraft carrier</a> entered service in 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-J15Carrier_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J15Carrier-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdet_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdet-211">[211]</a></sup> and it maintains a substantial fleet of <a href="/wiki/Submarines" title="Submarines" class="mw-redirect">submarines</a>, including several <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_submarine" title="Nuclear submarine">nuclear-powered</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nuclear_attack_submarine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nuclear attack submarine (page does not exist)">attack</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile</a> submarines.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> China has furthermore established a <a href="/w/index.php?title=String_of_Pearls_(China)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="String of Pearls (China) (page does not exist)">network of foreign military relationships along critical sea lanes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chinese_honor_guard_in_column_070322-F-0193C-014.JPEG" title="File:Chinese honor guard in column 070322-F-0193C-014.JPEG">File:Chinese honor guard in column 070322-F-0193C-014.JPEG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Members of a Chinese military honor guard</div></div></div>
<p>China has made significant progress in modernizing its air force since the early 2000s, purchasing Russian fighter jets such as the <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-30" title="Sukhoi Su-30">Sukhoi Su-30</a>, and also manufacturing its own modern fighters, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Chengdu_J-10" title="Chengdu J-10">Chengdu J-10</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shenyang_J-11&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shenyang J-11 (page does not exist)">Shenyang J-11</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shenyang_J-15&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shenyang J-15 (page does not exist)">J-15</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=J-16&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="J-16 (page does not exist)">J-16</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-J15Carrier_208-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J15Carrier-208">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009f_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009f-214">[214]</a></sup> China is furthermore engaged in developing an indigenous <a href="/wiki/Stealth_aircraft" title="Stealth aircraft">stealth aircraft</a> and numerous <a href="/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle" title="Unmanned aerial vehicle">combat drones</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Defense_Update_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Defense_Update-217">[217]</a></sup> China has also updated its ground forces, replacing its ageing <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet</a>-derived <a href="/w/index.php?title=Main_battle_tank&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Main battle tank (page does not exist)">tank inventory</a> with numerous variants of the modern <a href="/wiki/Type_99" title="Type 99">Type 99</a> tank, and upgrading its battlefield <a href="/w/index.php?title=C4ISTAR&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="C4ISTAR (page does not exist)">C3I</a> and <a href="/wiki/C4I" title="C4I" class="mw-redirect">C4I</a> systems to enhance its <a href="/wiki/Network-centric_warfare" title="Network-centric warfare">network-centric warfare</a> capabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> In addition, China has developed or acquired numerous advanced missile systems,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdes_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdes-219">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2008e_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2008e-220">[220]</a></sup> including <a href="/w/index.php?title=2007_Chinese_anti-satellite_missile_test&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2007 Chinese anti-satellite missile test (page does not exist)">anti-satellite missiles</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cruise_missile" title="Cruise missile">cruise missiles</a><sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup> and submarine-launched nuclear ICBMs.<sup id="cite_ref-WashTiNu_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WashTiNu-223">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shanghaistockexchange.jpg" title="File:Shanghaistockexchange.jpg">File:Shanghaistockexchange.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Stock_Exchange" title="Shanghai Stock Exchange">Shanghai Stock Exchange</a> building in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lujiazui&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lujiazui (page does not exist)">Lujiazui</a> financial district. Shanghai has the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_cities_by_GDP&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of cities by GDP (page does not exist)">25th-largest city GDP</a> in the world, totalling US$304 billion in 2011<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>As of 2013, China has <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">the world's second-largest economy</a> in terms of nominal GDP, totalling approximately US$9.3253&#160;trillion according to the National Bureau of Statistics of the People's Republic of China.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_6-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-6">[6]</a></sup> If <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP) is taken into account (US$12.405 trillion in 2012, US$14.9614 trillion in 2013), China's economy is again second only to the United States. In 2013, its PPP GDP per capita was US$10,253,<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_6-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-6">[6]</a></sup> while nominal GDP per capita was US$6,853. Both cases put China <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">behind around ninety countries</a> (out of 183 countries on the IMF list) in global GDP per capita rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-imf2_6-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-imf2-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Economic_history_and_growth">Economic history and growth</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
From its founding in 1949 until late 1978, the People's Republic of China was a Soviet-style centrally <a href="/wiki/Planned_economy" title="Planned economy">planned economy</a>. Following Mao's death in 1976 and the consequent end of the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping" title="Deng Xiaoping">Deng Xiaoping</a> and the new Chinese leadership began to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Economic_reform_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Economic reform in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">reform the economy</a> and move towards a more market-oriented <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> under one-party rule. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Collective_farming&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Collective farming (page does not exist)">Agricultural collectivization</a> was dismantled and farmlands privatized, while foreign trade became a major new focus, leading to the creation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Special_Economic_Zone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Special Economic Zone (page does not exist)">Special Economic Zones</a> (SEZs). Inefficient <a href="/wiki/Government-owned_corporation" title="Government-owned corporation">state-owned enterprises</a> (SOEs) were restructured and unprofitable ones were closed outright, resulting in massive job losses. Modern-day China is mainly characterized as having a market economy based on private property ownership,<sup id="cite_ref-english.eastday_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-english.eastday-225">[225]</a></sup> and is one of the leading examples of <a href="/wiki/State_capitalism" title="State capitalism">state capitalism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> The state still dominates in strategic "pillar" sectors such as energy production and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">heavy industries</a>, but private enterprise has expanded enormously, with around 30&#160;million private businesses recorded in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abf_228-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abf-228">[228]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Englishpeopledailycomcn2005-229">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2005a_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2005a-230">[230]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abg_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abg-231">[231]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Shanghai_-_Nanjing_Road.jpeg" title="File:Shanghai - Nanjing Road.jpeg">File:Shanghai - Nanjing Road.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Nanjing_Road_(Shanghai)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nanjing Road (Shanghai) (page does not exist)">Nanjing Road</a>, a major shopping street in Shanghai</div></div></div>
<p>Since economic liberalization began in 1978, China has been among the world's fastest-growing economies,<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup>  relying largely on investment- and export-led growth.<sup id="cite_ref-chinadaily_233-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chinadaily-233">[233]</a></sup> According to the IMF, China's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annual_average_GDP_growth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annual average GDP growth (page does not exist)">annual average GDP growth</a> between 2001 and 2010 was 10.5%. Between 2007 and 2011, China's economic growth rate was equivalent to all of the <a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> countries' growth combined.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=3G_(countries)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="3G (countries) (page does not exist)">Global Growth Generators</a> index announced by <a href="/wiki/Citigroup" title="Citigroup">Citigroup</a> in February 2011, China has a very high 3G growth rating.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> Its high productivity, low labor costs and relatively good infrastructure have made it a global leader in manufacturing. However, the Chinese economy is highly energy-intensive and inefficient;<sup id="cite_ref-China_Quick_Facts_236-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-China_Quick_Facts-236">[236]</a></sup> China became the world's largest <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_energy_resources_and_consumption&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World energy resources and consumption (page does not exist)">energy consumer</a> in 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-Swartz2010_237-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Swartz2010-237">[237]</a></sup> relies on coal to supply over 70% of its energy needs, and surpassed the US to become the world's largest oil importer in September 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-BusInsEnergyGuide_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BusInsEnergyGuide-238">[238]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> China's economic growth and industrialization has damaged its environment. In the early 2010s, China's economic growth rate began to slow amid domestic credit troubles, weakening international demand for Chinese exports, and global economic turmoil.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="China_in_the_global_economy">China in the global economy</span></h3>
<p>China is a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> and is the world's largest trading power, with a total international trade value of US$3.87&#160;trillion in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-ChinaBiggestTrader_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaBiggestTrader-12">[12]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foreign_exchange_reserves_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foreign exchange reserves of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">Its foreign exchange reserves</a> reached US$2.85&#160;trillion by the end of 2010, an increase of 18.7% over the previous year, making its reserves by far the world's largest.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009b_243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009b-243">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> As of 2009, China owns an estimated $1.6&#160;trillion of US <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">securities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2009c_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2009c-245">[245]</a></sup> China, holding over US$1.16 trillion in US <a href="/wiki/Treasury_bond" title="Treasury bond" class="mw-redirect">Treasury bonds</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> is the largest foreign holder of <a href="/w/index.php?title=US_public_debt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="US public debt (page does not exist)">US public debt</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abe_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abe-247">[247]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hornby2009_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hornby2009-248">[248]</a></sup> In 2012, China was the world's largest recipient of inward <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI), attracting $253 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-FDI_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-249">[249]</a></sup> China also invests abroad, with a total outward FDI of $62.4&#160;billion in 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-FDI_249-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FDI-249">[249]</a></sup> and a number of major takeovers of foreign firms by Chinese companies.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup> China's undervalued exchange rate has caused friction with other major economies,<sup id="cite_ref-CurrencyManipulator_166-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CurrencyManipulator-166">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2008_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2008-251">[251]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2005_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2005-252">[252]</a></sup> and it has also been widely criticized for manufacturing large quantities of <a href="/wiki/Counterfeit" title="Counterfeit">counterfeit</a> goods.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup>
</p>
