<p>China ranked 29th in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Global_Competitiveness_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Global Competitiveness Index (page does not exist)">Global Competitiveness Index</a> in 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abh_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abh-256">[256]</a></sup> although it is only ranked 136th among the 179 countries measured in the 2011 <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">Index of Economic Freedom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup> In 2011, 61 Chinese companies were listed in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fortune_Global_500&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fortune Global 500 (page does not exist)">Fortune Global 500</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abi_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abi-258">[258]</a></sup> Measured by total revenues, three of the world's top ten most valuable companies in 2011 were Chinese, including fifth-ranked <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sinopec_Group&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sinopec Group (page does not exist)">Sinopec Group</a>, sixth-ranked <a href="/w/index.php?title=China_National_Petroleum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China National Petroleum (page does not exist)">China National Petroleum</a> and seventh-ranked <a href="/wiki/State_Grid_Corporation_of_China" title="State Grid Corporation of China">State Grid</a> (the world's largest electric utilities company).<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abi_258-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abi-258">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Class_and_income_equality">Class and income equality</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
China's middle-class population (if defined as those with annual income of between US$10,000 and US$60,000) had reached more than 300&#160;million by 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hurun_Report&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hurun Report (page does not exist)">Hurun Report</a>, the number of US dollar billionaires in China increased from 130 in 2009 to 251 in 2012, giving China the world's second-highest number of billionaires.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> China's domestic retail market was worth over 20 trillion yuan (US$3.2 trillion) in 2012<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> and is growing at over 12% annually as of 2013,<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> while the country's luxury goods market has expanded immensely, with 27.5% of the global share.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abq_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abq-264">[264]</a></sup> However, in recent years, China's rapid economic growth has contributed to severe consumer inflation,<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> leading to increased government regulation.<sup id="cite_ref-FT9.1_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT9.1-267">[267]</a></sup> China has a high level of economic inequality,<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> which has increased in the past few decades.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> In 2012, China's <a href="/wiki/Gini_coefficient" title="Gini coefficient">Gini coefficient</a> was 0.474.<sup id="cite_ref-gini_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gini-7">[7]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Internationalization_of_the_renminbi">Internationalization of the renminbi</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In November 2010, Russia began using the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_renminbi&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese renminbi (page does not exist)">Chinese renminbi</a> in its bilateral trade with China.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> This was soon followed by Japan,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-massg_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-massg-273">[273]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> As a result of the rapid internationalization of the renminbi, it became the eighth-most-traded currency in the world in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:History_of_science_and_technology_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:History of science and technology in China (page does not exist)">Template:History of science and technology in China</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical">Historical</span></h3>
<p>China was a world leader in science and technology until the <a href="/wiki/Ming_Dynasty" title="Ming Dynasty">Ming Dynasty</a>. Ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Chinese_discoveries&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Chinese discoveries (page does not exist)">Chinese discoveries</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Chinese_inventions&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Chinese inventions (page does not exist)">inventions</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Papermaking" title="Papermaking">papermaking</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_typography_in_East_Asia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of typography in East Asia (page does not exist)">printing</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Compass" title="Compass">compass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gunpowder" title="Gunpowder">gunpowder</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Four_Great_Inventions" title="Four Great Inventions">Four Great Inventions</a>), later became widespread in Asia and Europe. Chinese mathematicians were the first to use <a href="/wiki/Negative_numbers#History" title="Negative numbers" class="mw-redirect">negative numbers</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> However, by the 17th century, the Western world had surpassed China in scientific and technological development.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> The causes of this <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Divergence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Divergence (page does not exist)">Great Divergence</a> continue to be debated.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>After repeated military defeats by Western nations in the 19th century, Chinese reformers began promoting modern science and technology as part of the <a href="/wiki/Self-Strengthening_Movement" title="Self-Strengthening Movement">Self-Strengthening Movement</a>. After the Communists came to power in 1949, efforts were made to organize science and technology based on the model of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>, in which scientific research was part of central planning.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> After Mao's death in 1976, science and technology was established as one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Modernizations" title="Four Modernizations">Four Modernizations</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> and the Soviet-inspired academic system was gradually reformed.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_era">Modern era</span></h3>
<p>Since the end of the Cultural Revolution, China has made significant investments in scientific research,<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup> spending over US$100 billion on scientific research and development in 2011 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[284]</a></sup> Science and technology are seen as vital for achieving economic and political goals, and are held as a source of national pride to a degree sometimes described as "techno-nationalism".<sup id="cite_ref-TeNat_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TeNat-285">[285]</a></sup> While Chinese-born scientists have won the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physics" title="Nobel Prize in Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> four times and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry (page does not exist)">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> once, these scientists had all earned their doctorates and conducted their award-winning research in the West.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Launch_of_Long_March_3B_Rocket.jpg" title="File:The Launch of Long March 3B Rocket.jpg">File:The Launch of Long March 3B Rocket.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The launch of a Chinese <a href="/w/index.php?title=Long_March_3B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Long March 3B (page does not exist)">Long March 3B</a> rocket</div></div></div>
<p>China is rapidly developing its education system with an emphasis on <a href="/w/index.php?title=STEM_fields&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="STEM fields (page does not exist)">science, mathematics and engineering</a>; in 2009, it produced over 10,000 Ph.D. engineering graduates, and as many as 500,000 <a href="/wiki/BSc" title="BSc" class="mw-redirect">BSc</a> graduates, more than any other country.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> China is also the world's second-largest publisher of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academic_publishing_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academic publishing in China (page does not exist)">scientific papers</a>, producing 121,500 in 2010 alone, including 5,200 in leading international scientific journals.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> Chinese technology companies such as <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lenovo" title="Lenovo">Lenovo</a> have become world leaders in telecommunications and personal computing,<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> and Chinese <a href="/wiki/Supercomputer" title="Supercomputer">supercomputers</a> are consistently ranked among the <a href="/w/index.php?title=TOP500&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="TOP500 (page does not exist)">world's most powerful</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> Currently China is experiencing a significant growth in the use of industrial robots; from 2008 to 2011, the installation of multi-role robots has risen by 136 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Chinese space program is one of the world's most active, and is a major source of national pride.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> In 1970, China launched its first satellite, <a href="/wiki/Dong_Fang_Hong_I" title="Dong Fang Hong I">Dong Fang Hong I</a>. In 2003, China became the third country to independently send humans into space, with <a href="/wiki/Yang_Liwei" title="Yang Liwei">Yang Liwei</a>'s spaceflight aboard <a href="/wiki/Shenzhou_5" title="Shenzhou 5">Shenzhou 5</a>; as of June 2013, <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Chinese_astronauts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Chinese astronauts (page does not exist)">ten Chinese nationals</a> have journeyed into space. In 2011, China's first space station module, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiangong-1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tiangong-1 (page does not exist)">Tiangong-1</a>, was launched, marking the first step in a project to assemble <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_space_station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese space station (page does not exist)">a large manned station</a> by the early 2020s.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communications">Communications</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
China currently has the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_number_of_mobile_phones_in_use&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by number of mobile phones in use (page does not exist)">largest number of active cellphones</a> of any country in the world, with over 1 billion users by February 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> It also has the world's largest number of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_number_of_Internet_users&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by number of Internet users (page does not exist)">internet</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_countries_by_number_of_broadband_Internet_users&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of countries by number of broadband Internet users (page does not exist)">broadband users</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Barboza2008_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barboza2008-298">[298]</a></sup> with over 591 million internet users as of 2013, equivalent to around 44% of its population.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup> A 2013 report found that the national average internet connection speed is 3.14 MB/s.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> As of July 2013, China accounts for 24% of the world's internet-connected devices.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/China_Telecom" title="China Telecom">China Telecom</a> and <a href="/wiki/China_Unicom" title="China Unicom">China Unicom</a>, the world's two largest broadband providers, accounted for 20% of global broadband subscribers. China Telecom alone serves more than 50 million broadband subscribers, while China Unicom serves more than 40 million.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abca_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abca-302">[302]</a></sup> Several Chinese telecommunications companies, most notably <a href="/wiki/Huawei" title="Huawei">Huawei</a> and <a href="/wiki/ZTE" title="ZTE">ZTE</a>, have been accused of spying for the Chinese military.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jingshen_Expwy_Jul2004.jpg" title="File:Jingshen Expwy Jul2004.jpg">File:Jingshen Expwy Jul2004.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Jingshen_Expressway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jingshen Expressway (page does not exist)">Jingshen Expressway</a></div></div></div>
<p>Since the late 1990s, China's national road network has been significantly expanded through the creation of a network of <a href="/wiki/Expressways_of_China" title="Expressways of China">highways</a>, known as the National Trunk Highway System (NTHS). In 2011 China's highways had reached a total length of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, making it the longest highway system in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Private car ownership is growing rapidly in China, which surpassed the United States as the world's largest automobile market in 2009, with total car sales of over 13.6&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2010c_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2010c-305">[305]</a></sup> Analysts predict that annual car sales in China may rise as high as 40 million by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> A side-effect of the rapid growth of China's road network has been a significant rise in traffic accidents,<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> with poorly enforced traffic laws cited as a possible cause—in 2011 alone, around 62,000 Chinese died in road accidents.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> In urban areas, bicycles remain a common mode of transport, despite the increasing prevalence of automobiles – as of 2012, there are approximately 470 million bicycles in China.<sup id="cite_ref-470MBikes_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-309">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>China's railways, owned by the state,<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> are the busiest in the world, handling a quarter of the world's cargo and passenger travel.<sup id="cite_ref-overcrowding_311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overcrowding-311">[311]</a></sup> Due to huge demand, the system is regularly subject to overcrowding, particularly during holiday seasons, such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Chunyun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chunyun (page does not exist)">Chunyun</a></i> during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_New_Year&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese New Year (page does not exist)">Chinese New Year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-overcrowding_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-overcrowding-311">[311]</a></sup> The Chinese rail network carried an estimated 1.68 billion total passengers in 2010 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-AFPviaRaw_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFPviaRaw-312">[312]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:A_maglev_train_coming_out,_Pudong_International_Airport,_Shanghai.jpg" title="File:A maglev train coming out, Pudong International Airport, Shanghai.jpg">File:A maglev train coming out, Pudong International Airport, Shanghai.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A high-speed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maglev_(transport)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maglev (transport) (page does not exist)">maglev train</a> leaving <a href="/wiki/Pudong_International_Airport" title="Pudong International Airport" class="mw-redirect">Pudong International Airport</a>, Shanghai, in 2006</div></div></div>
<p>More than 10,000&#160;km of China's railway mileage—over 100,000&#160;km in total—are high-speed lines.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup>  In December 2012, China opened the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beijing%E2%80%93Guangzhou%E2%80%93Shenzhen%E2%80%93Hong_Kong_High-Speed_Railway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beijing–Guangzhou–Shenzhen–Hong Kong High-Speed Railway (page does not exist)">world's longest high-speed rail line</a>, running from Beijing to Guangzhou.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> China intends to operate approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of high-speed rail lines by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-AFPviaRaw_312-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFPviaRaw-312">[312]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">Rapid transit</a> systems are also rapidly developing in China's major cities, in the form of networks of underground or <a href="/wiki/Light_rail" title="Light rail">light rail</a> systems.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> China is additionally developing its own <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation" title="Satellite navigation">satellite navigation</a> system, dubbed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beidou_navigation_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beidou navigation system (page does not exist)">Beidou</a>, which began offering commercial navigation services across Asia in 2012,<sup id="cite_ref-CustomersDec2012_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CustomersDec2012-316">[316]</a></sup> and is planned to offer global coverage by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2013, more than two-thirds of airports under construction worldwide are in China,<sup id="cite_ref-airlines_318-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-airlines-318">[318]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boeing&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boeing (page does not exist)">Boeing</a> expects that China's fleet of active commercial aircraft in China will grow from 1,910 to 2011 to 5,980 in 2031.<sup id="cite_ref-airlines_318-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-airlines-318">[318]</a></sup> However, 80% of China's airspace remains restricted for military use, and Chinese airlines made up eight of the 10 worst-performing Asian airlines in terms of delays.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:PRC_Population_Density.svg" title="File:PRC Population Density.svg">File:PRC Population Density.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A 2009 population density map of the People's Republic of China. The eastern coastal provinces are much more densely populated than the western interior</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sixth_National_Population_Census_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sixth National Population Census of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">national census of 2010</a> recorded the population of the People's Republic of China as approximately 1,370,536,875. About 16.60% of the population were 14 years old or younger, 70.14% were between 15 and 59 years old, and 13.26% were over 60 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> The population growth rate for 2013 is estimated to be 0.46%.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although a middle-income country by Western standards, China's rapid growth has <a href="/w/index.php?title=Poverty_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Poverty in China (page does not exist)">pulled hundreds of millions</a> of its people out of poverty since 1978. Today, about 10% of the Chinese population lives below the poverty line of US$1 per day, down from 64% in 1978. Urban unemployment in China reportedly declined to 4% by the end of 2007, although true overall unemployment may be as high as 10%.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abm_322-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abm-322">[322]</a></sup>
</p><p>With a population of over 1.3 billion and dwindling natural resources, the government of China is very concerned about its population growth rate and has attempted since 1979, with mixed results,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcf_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcf-323">[323]</a></sup> to implement a strict <a href="/wiki/Family_planning" title="Family planning">family planning</a> policy, known as the "<a href="/wiki/One-child_policy" title="One-child policy">one-child policy</a>." Before 2013, this policy sought to restrict families to one child each, with exceptions for ethnic minorities and a degree of flexibility in rural areas. A major loosening of the policy was enacted in December 2013, allowing families to have two children if one parent is an only child.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup> China's family planning minister indicated in 2008 that the one-child policy would be maintained until at least 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2008b_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2008b-325">[325]</a></sup> The one-child policy is resisted, particularly in rural areas, primarily because of the need for agricultural labour and a traditional preference for boys. Families who breach the policy often lie during the census.<sup id="cite_ref-censuslie_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-censuslie-326">[326]</a></sup> Data from the 2010 census implies that the <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> may now be around 1.4.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Population_and_Natural_Increase_Rate_of_PRC.jpg" title="File:Population and Natural Increase Rate of PRC.jpg">File:Population and Natural Increase Rate of PRC.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Population of China from 1949 to 2008</div></div></div>
<p>The policy, along with traditional preference for boys, may be contributing to an imbalance in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_sex_ratio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human sex ratio (page does not exist)">sex ratio</a> at birth.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_2007a_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_2007a-329">[329]</a></sup> According to the 2010 census, the sex ration at birth was 118.06 boys for every 100 girls,<sup id="cite_ref-genderratio_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-330">[330]</a></sup> which is beyond the normal range of around 105 boys for every 100 girls.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup> The 2010 census found that males accounted for 51.27 percent of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-genderratio_330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-330">[330]</a></sup> However, China's sex ratio is more balanced than it was in 1953, when males accounted for 51.82 percent of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-genderratio_330-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-genderratio-330">[330]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>China officially recognizes 56 distinct ethnic groups, the largest of
which are the <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a>, who constitute about 91.51% of the total
population.<sup id="cite_ref-groups_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-groups-4">[4]</a></sup> The Han Chinese – the world's largest single ethnic group<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> – outnumber other ethnic groups in every provincial-level division except <a href="/wiki/Tibet_Autonomous_Region" title="Tibet Autonomous Region">Tibet</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Xinjiang&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Xinjiang (page does not exist)">Xinjiang</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> Ethnic minorities account for about 8.49% of the population of China, according to
the 2010 census.<sup id="cite_ref-groups_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-groups-4">[4]</a></sup> Compared with the 2000 population census, the Han population increased by 66,537,177 persons, or 5.74%, while the population of the 55 national minorities combined increased by 7,362,627 persons, or 6.92%.<sup id="cite_ref-groups_4-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-groups-4">[4]</a></sup> The 2010 census recorded a total of 593,832 foreign citizens living in China. The largest such groups were from South Korea (120,750), the
United States (71,493) and Japan (66,159).<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:China_linguistic_map.jpg" title="File:China linguistic map.jpg">File:China linguistic map.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">1990 map of Chinese ethnolinguistic groups</div></div></div>
<p>The languages most spoken in China belong to the <a href="/wiki/Sino-Tibetan_language" title="Sino-Tibetan language" class="mw-redirect">Sino-Tibetan language</a> family. There are also several major <a href="/wiki/Varieties_of_Chinese" title="Varieties of Chinese">linguistic groups</a> within the Chinese language itself. The most spoken varieties are <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">Mandarin</a> (spoken by 70% of the population<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Wu_Chinese" title="Wu Chinese">Wu</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Shanghainese" title="Shanghainese">Shanghainese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Yue_Chinese" title="Yue Chinese">Yue</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Cantonese" title="Cantonese">Cantonese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taishanese" title="Taishanese">Taishanese</a>), <a href="/wiki/Min_Chinese" title="Min Chinese">Min</a> (including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hokkien&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hokkien (page does not exist)">Hokkien</a> and <a href="/wiki/Teochew_dialect" title="Teochew dialect">Teochew</a>), <a href="/wiki/Xiang_Chinese" title="Xiang Chinese">Xiang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gan_Chinese" title="Gan Chinese">Gan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hakka_Chinese" title="Hakka Chinese">Hakka</a>. Non-Sinitic languages spoken widely by ethnic minorities include <a href="/wiki/Zhuang_languages" title="Zhuang languages">Zhuang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_language" title="Mongolian language">Mongolian</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Standard_Tibetan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Standard Tibetan (page does not exist)">Tibetan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uyghur_language" title="Uyghur language">Uyghur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hmong_language" title="Hmong language">Hmong</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_language" title="Korean language">Korean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-language_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-language-336">[336]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Standard_Chinese" title="Standard Chinese">Standard Mandarin</a>, a variety of Mandarin based on the <a href="/wiki/Beijing_dialect" title="Beijing dialect">Beijing dialect</a>, is the official national language of China and is used as a <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> in the country between people of different linguistic backgrounds.<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese" title="Classical Chinese">Classical Chinese</a> was the written standard in China for thousands of years and allowed for written communication between speakers of various unintelligible languages and dialects in China. <a href="/wiki/Written_vernacular_Chinese" title="Written vernacular Chinese">Written vernacular Chinese</a>, or <i>baihua</i>, is the written standard, based on the Mandarin dialect and first popularized in Ming Dynasty novels. It was adopted, with significant modifications, during the early 20th century as the national standard. Classical Chinese is still part of the high school curriculum, and is thus intelligible to some degree to many Chinese. Since their promulgation by the government in 1956, <a href="/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters" title="Simplified Chinese characters">Simplified Chinese characters</a> have become the official standardized <a href="/w/index.php?title=Writing_system&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Writing system (page does not exist)">written script</a> used to <a href="/wiki/Written_Chinese" title="Written Chinese">write the Chinese language</a> within mainland China, supplanting the use of the earlier <a href="/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters" title="Traditional Chinese characters">Traditional Chinese characters</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>China has urbanized significantly in the past few decades. The percent of the country's population living in urban areas increased from 20% in 1990 to 46% in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-338">[338]</a></sup> It is estimated that China's urban population will reach one billion by 2030.<sup id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_338-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-338">[338]</a></sup> As of 2012, there are more than 262&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Migrant_worker" title="Migrant worker">migrant workers</a> in China.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> Most of them are from rural areas and seek work in the cities.
</p><p>China has over 160 cities with a population of over one million,<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> including the seven <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacities</a> (cities with a population of over 10 million) of Chongqing, Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou, Tianjin, Shenzhen, and Wuhan.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup> By 2025, it is estimated that the country will be home to 221 cities with over a million inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-McKinseyUrbanBillion_338-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-McKinseyUrbanBillion-338">[338]</a></sup> The figures in the table below are from the 2010 census,<sup id="cite_ref-census_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census-344">[344]</a></sup> and are only estimates of the urban populations within administrative city limits; a different ranking exists when considering the total municipal populations (which includes suburban and rural populations). The large "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Floating_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Floating population (page does not exist)">floating populations</a>" of migrant workers make conducting censuses in urban areas difficult;<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abce_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abce-345">[345]</a></sup> the figures below include only long-term residents.
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest cities of China (page does not exist)">Template:Largest cities of China</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tsinghua_Observatory.jpg" title="File:Tsinghua Observatory.jpg">File:Tsinghua Observatory.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Beijing's <a href="/wiki/Tsinghua_University" title="Tsinghua University">Tsinghua University</a>, one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_university_ranking_(Wu_Shulian)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese university ranking (Wu Shulian) (page does not exist)">top-ranked universities in China</a><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Since 1986, compulsory education in China comprises <a href="/wiki/Primary_school" title="Primary school">primary</a> and <a href="/wiki/Middle_school" title="Middle school">junior secondary school</a>, which together last for nine years.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> In 2010, about 82.5 percent of students continued their education at a three-year senior secondary school.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gaokao&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gaokao (page does not exist)">Gaokao</a>, China's national university entrance exam, is a prerequisite for entrance into most higher education institutions. In 2010, 27 percent of secondary school graduates are enrolled in higher education.<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[349]</a></sup> Vocational education is available to students at the secondary and <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">tertiary</a> level.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[350]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 2006, the government pledged to provide completely free nine-year education, including textbooks and fees.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abch_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abch-351">[351]</a></sup> Annual education investment went from less than US$50 billion in 2003 to more than US$250 billion in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> However, there remains an inequality in education spending. In 2010, the annual education expenditure per secondary school student in Beijing totaled ¥20,023, while in <a href="/wiki/Guizhou" title="Guizhou">Guizhou</a>, one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Chinese_administrative_divisions_by_GDP_per_capita" title="List of Chinese administrative divisions by GDP per capita">poorest provinces in China</a>, only totaled ¥3,204.<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup> Free compulsory education in China consists of primary school and junior secondary school between the ages of 6 and 15. In 2011, around 81.4% of Chinese have received secondary education.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[354]</a></sup> By 2007, there were 396,567 primary schools, 94,116 secondary schools, and 2,236 higher education institutions in China.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:As_of&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:As of (page does not exist)">Template:As of</a>, 94% of the population over age 15 are literate,<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> compared to only 20% in 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abl_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abl-357">[357]</a></sup> In 2009, Chinese students from Shanghai achieved the world's best results in mathematics, science and literacy, as tested by the <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">Programme for International Student Assessment</a> (PISA), a worldwide evaluation of 15-year-old school pupils' scholastic performance.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:China_Human_Dev_SVG.svg" title="File:China Human Dev SVG.svg">File:China Human Dev SVG.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Chart showing the rise of China's <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> from 1970 to 2010</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ministry_of_Health_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">Ministry of Health</a>, together with its counterparts in the provincial health bureaux, oversees the health needs of the Chinese population.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[359]</a></sup> An emphasis on public health and preventive medicine has characterized Chinese health policy since the early 1950s. At that time, the Communist Party started the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patriotic_Health_Campaign&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patriotic Health Campaign (page does not exist)">Patriotic Health Campaign</a>, which was aimed at improving sanitation and hygiene, as well as treating and preventing several diseases. Diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Typhoid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Typhoid (page does not exist)">typhoid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scarlet_fever" title="Scarlet fever">scarlet fever</a>, which were previously rife in China, were nearly eradicated by the campaign. After Deng Xiaoping began instituting economic reforms in 1978, the health of the Chinese public improved rapidly due to better nutrition, although many of the free public health services provided in the countryside disappeared along with the People's Communes. Healthcare in China became mostly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Private_healthcare&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Private healthcare (page does not exist)">privatized</a>, and experienced a significant rise in quality. In 2009, the government began a 3-year large-scale healthcare provision initiative worth US$124 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[360]</a></sup> By 2011, the campaign resulted in 95% of China's population having basic health insurance coverage.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup> In 2011, China was estimated to be the world's third-largest supplier of <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" title="Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect">pharmaceuticals</a>, but its population has suffered from the development and distribution of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Counterfeit_medications&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Counterfeit medications (page does not exist)">counterfeit medications</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[362]</a></sup>
</p><p>Life expectancy at birth in China is 75 years,<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[363]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> rate is 12 per thousand.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup> Both have improved significantly since the 1950s.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> Rates of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stunted_growth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stunted growth (page does not exist)">stunting</a>, a condition caused by <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, have declined from 33.1% in 1990 to 9.9% in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[365]</a></sup> Despite significant improvements in health and the construction of advanced medical facilities, China has several emerging public health problems, such as respiratory illnesses caused by <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_China" title="Environment of China">widespread air pollution</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FT-china-pollution_366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FT-china-pollution-366">[366]</a></sup> hundreds of millions of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco_smoking" title="Tobacco smoking">cigarette smokers</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcx_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcx-367">[367]</a></sup> and an increase in <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">obesity</a> among urban youths.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcy_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcy-368">[368]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcz_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcz-369">[369]</a></sup> China's large population and densely populated cities have led to serious disease outbreaks in recent years, such as the 2003 outbreak of <a href="/wiki/Severe_acute_respiratory_syndrome" title="Severe acute respiratory syndrome">SARS</a>, although this has since been largely contained.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcda_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcda-370">[370]</a></sup> In 2010, air pollution caused 1.2 million premature deaths in China.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Guoqingsi001r.jpg" title="File:Guoqingsi001r.jpg">File:Guoqingsi001r.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Guoqing_Temple&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guoqing Temple (page does not exist)">Guoqing Temple</a> on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tiantai_Mountain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tiantai Mountain (page does not exist)">Mount Tiantai</a>, built in 598 CE, was the founding site of the <a href="/wiki/Tiantai" title="Tiantai">Tiantai</a> branch of Chinese Buddhism.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">Freedom of religion</a> is guaranteed by China's constitution, although religious organizations that lack official approval can be subject to state persecution.<sup id="cite_ref-XinBan2012_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-XinBan2012-192">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[372]</a></sup> Estimates of religious demographics in China vary. A 2007 survey found that 31.4 percent of Chinese above the age of 16 were religious,<sup id="cite_ref-news.bbc.co.uk_373-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-news.bbc.co.uk-373">[373]</a></sup> while a 2006 study found that 46% of the Chinese population were religious.<sup id="cite_ref-ECRAN2012_374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECRAN2012-374">[374]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the millennia, the Chinese civilization has been influenced by various religious movements. China's <i><a href="/wiki/Three_teachings" title="Three teachings">San Jiao</a></i> ("three doctrines" or "three religions") include <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a>,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Efn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Efn (page does not exist)">Template:Efn</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhism (page does not exist)">Buddhism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>, and historically have had a significant impact in shaping Chinese culture.<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[376]</a></sup> Elements of these three belief systems are often incorporated into <a href="/wiki/Chinese_folk_religion" title="Chinese folk religion">popular or folk religious traditions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[377]</a></sup> A 2008 survey of rural villagers in six provinces found that
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">more than two-thirds of self-proclaimed religious believers (or 31.09% of all sample villagers) do not or cannot clearly identify their faith&#160;... These people believe that there are supernatural powers that dominate or strongly influence the fate of human beings, and they think their fates can be changed through offering sacrifices to gods or ancestors. These beliefs and practices are often deeply rooted in traditional Chinese cultures and customs of local communities.<sup id="cite_ref-ECRAN2012_374-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECRAN2012-374">[374]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>A 2007 survey by the Horizon Research Consultancy Group found that individuals who self-identify as Buddhists made up 11–16% of China's adult population, while <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians" class="mw-redirect">Christians</a> comprised around 3–4%, and <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims" class="mw-redirect">Muslims</a> comprised approximately 1%.<sup id="cite_ref-pewforum.org_378-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pewforum.org-378">[378]</a></sup> Some of the <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_China" title="Ethnic minorities in China">ethnic minorities of China</a> practice unique <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_religion" title="Ethnic religion">ethnic religions</a> – <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dongbaism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dongbaism (page does not exist)">Dongbaism</a> is the traditional religion of the <a href="/wiki/Nakhi_people" title="Nakhi people">Nakhi people</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moism_(Zhuang_religion)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Moism (Zhuang religion) (page does not exist)">Moism</a> that of the <a href="/wiki/Zhuang_people" title="Zhuang people">Zhuang people</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ruism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ruism (page does not exist)">Ruism</a> that of the <a href="/wiki/Qiang_people" title="Qiang people">Qiang people</a>. The traditional indigenous religion of <a href="/wiki/Tibet" title="Tibet">Tibet</a> is <a href="/w/index.php?title=B%C3%B6n&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bön (page does not exist)">Bön</a>, while most <a href="/wiki/Tibetans" title="Tibetans" class="mw-redirect">Tibetans</a> follow <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_Buddhism" title="Tibetan Buddhism">Tibetan Buddhism</a>, a form of <a href="/wiki/Vajrayana" title="Vajrayana">Vajrayana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Multiple_image&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Multiple image (page does not exist)">Template:Multiple image</a>
Since ancient times, Chinese culture has been heavily influenced by <a href="/wiki/Confucianism" title="Confucianism">Confucianism</a> and conservative philosophies. For much of the country's dynastic era, opportunities for social advancement could be provided by high performance in the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Imperial_examination" title="Imperial examination">imperial examinations</a>, which have their origins in the <a href="/wiki/Han_Dynasty" title="Han Dynasty">Han Dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Chinese_literature" title="Chinese literature">literary emphasis</a> of the exams affected the general perception of cultural refinement in China, such as the belief that <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calligraphy" title="Chinese calligraphy">calligraphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Classical_Chinese_poetry" title="Classical Chinese poetry">poetry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_painting" title="Chinese painting">painting</a> were higher forms of art than dancing or drama. Chinese culture has long emphasized a sense of deep history and a largely inward-looking national perspective.<sup id="cite_ref-ChinaFuture_15-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChinaFuture-15">[15]</a></sup> Examinations and a <a href="/wiki/Meritocracy" title="Meritocracy">culture of merit</a> remain greatly valued in China today.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first leaders of the People's Republic of China were born into the traditional imperial order, but were influenced by the <a href="/wiki/May_Fourth_Movement" title="May Fourth Movement">May Fourth Movement</a> and reformist ideals. They sought to change some traditional aspects of Chinese culture, such as rural land tenure, <a href="/wiki/Sexism" title="Sexism">sexism</a>, and the Confucian system of education, while preserving others, such as the family structure and culture of obedience to the state. Some observers see the period following the establishment of the PRC in 1949 as a continuation of traditional Chinese dynastic history, while others claim that the Communist Party's rule has damaged the foundations of Chinese culture, especially through political movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Revolution" title="Cultural Revolution">Cultural Revolution</a> of the 1960s, where many aspects of traditional culture were destroyed, having been denounced as "regressive and harmful" or "vestiges of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>". Many important aspects of traditional Chinese morals and culture, such as Confucianism, art, literature, and performing arts like <a href="/wiki/Peking_opera" title="Peking opera">Peking opera</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcded_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcded-382">[382]</a></sup> were altered to conform to government policies and propaganda at the time. Access to foreign media remains heavily restricted; only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Censorship_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Censorship in China (page does not exist)">34 foreign films</a> a year are allowed to be shown in Chinese cinemas.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, the Chinese government has accepted numerous elements of traditional Chinese culture as being integral to Chinese society. With the rise of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_nationalism" title="Chinese nationalism">Chinese nationalism</a> and the end of the Cultural Revolution, various forms of traditional Chinese art, literature, music, film, fashion and architecture have seen a vigorous revival,<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdef_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdef-384">[384]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeg_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeg-385">[385]</a></sup> and folk and variety art in particular have sparked interest nationally and even worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeh_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeh-386">[386]</a></sup> China is now the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tourism_in_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tourism in China (page does not exist)">third-most-visited country in the world</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup> with 55.7&#160;million inbound international visitors in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abd_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abd-388">[388]</a></sup> It also experiences an enormous volume of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Domestic_tourism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Domestic tourism (page does not exist)">domestic tourism</a>; an estimated 740 million Chinese holidaymakers travelled within the country in October 2012 alone.<sup id="cite_ref-740MillionTourists_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-740MillionTourists-389">[389]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tianjin_lunch_of_Goubuli.jpg" title="File:Tianjin lunch of Goubuli.jpg">File:Tianjin lunch of Goubuli.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Traditional Chinese food in <a href="/wiki/Tianjin" title="Tianjin">Tianjin</a>, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_dumpling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese dumpling (page does not exist)">dumpling</a> and guobacai</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Chinese cuisine is highly diverse, drawing on several millennia of culinary history. The dynastic <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_China" title="Emperor of China">emperors</a> of ancient China were known to have many dining chambers in their palaces, with each chamber divided into several departments, each responsible for a specific type of dish.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[390]</a></sup> China's staple food is rice. Pork is the most popular meat in China, accounting for about three-fourths of the country's total meat consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[391]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Five-spice_powder" title="Five-spice powder">Spices</a> are central to Chinese cuisine. Numerous foreign offshoots of Chinese food, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuisine_of_Hong_Kong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuisine of Hong Kong (page does not exist)">Hong Kong cuisine</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Chinese_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Chinese food (page does not exist)">American Chinese food</a>, have emerged in the various nations that play host to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chinese_diaspora&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chinese diaspora (page does not exist)">Chinese diaspora</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dragon_boat_racing.jpg" title="File:Dragon boat racing.jpg">File:Dragon boat racing.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Dragon_boat" title="Dragon boat">Dragon boat</a> racing, a popular traditional Chinese sport</div></div></div>
<p>China has one of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sport_in_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sport in the People's Republic of China (page does not exist)">oldest sporting cultures</a> in the world. There is evidence that a form of <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">association football</a> called <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuju&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cuju (page does not exist)">cuju</a></i> was played in China during the Han Dynasty.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[392]</a></sup> Today, some of the most popular sports in the country include <a href="/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts" title="Chinese martial arts">martial arts</a>, basketball, football, table tennis, badminton, swimming and <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">snooker</a>. <a href="/wiki/Board_game" title="Board game">Board games</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Go_(board_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Go (board game) (page does not exist)">go</a> (known as <i>weiqi</i> in China), <a href="/wiki/Xiangqi" title="Xiangqi">xiangqi</a>, and more recently <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">chess</a>, are also played at a professional level.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[393]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Physical_fitness" title="Physical fitness">Physical fitness</a> is widely emphasized in Chinese culture, with morning exercises such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Qigong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Qigong (page does not exist)">qigong</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/T%27ai_chi_ch%27uan" title="T'ai chi ch'uan">t'ai chi ch'uan</a></i> widely practiced,<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[394]</a></sup> and commercial <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gym&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gym (page does not exist)">gyms</a> and fitness clubs gaining popularity in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup> Young people in China are also enjoy soccer and basketball, especially in urban centers with limited space and grass areas. The American <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a> has a huge following among the Chinese youth, with ethnic or native Chinese players such as <a href="/wiki/Yao_Ming" title="Yao Ming">Yao Ming</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jeremy_Lin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jeremy Lin (page does not exist)">Jeremy Lin</a> held in high esteem.<sup id="cite_ref-Beech2003_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beech2003-396">[396]</a></sup> In addition, China is home to a huge number of <a href="/wiki/Cycling" title="Cycling">cyclists</a>, with an estimated 470 million bicycles as of 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-470MBikes_309-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470MBikes-309">[309]</a></sup> Many more traditional sports, such as <a href="/wiki/Dragon_boat" title="Dragon boat">dragon boat</a> racing, <a href="/wiki/Mongolian_wrestling" title="Mongolian wrestling">Mongolian-style wrestling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Horse_racing" title="Horse racing">horse racing</a> are also popular.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcden_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcden-397">[397]</a></sup>
</p><p>China has <a href="/w/index.php?title=China_at_the_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China at the Olympics (page does not exist)">participated in the Olympic Games</a> since 1932, although it has only participated as the PRC <a href="/w/index.php?title=China_at_the_1952_Summer_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China at the 1952 Summer Olympics (page does not exist)">since 1952</a>. China hosted the <a href="/wiki/2008_Summer_Olympics" title="2008 Summer Olympics">2008 Summer Olympics</a> in Beijing, where its athletes received 51 gold medals – <a href="/w/index.php?title=2008_Summer_Olympics_medal_table&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2008 Summer Olympics medal table (page does not exist)">the highest number of gold medals</a> of any participating nation that year.<sup id="cite_ref-Ref_abcdeo_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ref_abcdeo-398">[398]</a></sup> China also won the most medals of any nation at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Paralympics" title="2012 Summer Paralympics">2012 Summer Paralympics</a>, with 231 overall, including 95 gold medals.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup> China hosted the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2013_East_Asian_Games&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2013 East Asian Games (page does not exist)">2013 East Asian Games</a> in Tianjin and will host the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2014_Summer_Youth_Olympics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2014 Summer Youth Olympics (page does not exist)">2014 Summer Youth Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nanjing" title="Nanjing">Nanjing</a>.
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
